On July 24, 2015, 1,000 taxi drivers in [[Rio de Janeiro]] blocked traffic during the morning rush hour. Lawmakers voted to ban Uber in São Paulo and Brasilia.<ref>{{cite news | title=Over a thousand Rio taxi drivers block main city route to protest Uber | url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2015/jul/24/rio-de-janeiro-uber-protest-taxis | work=[[The Guardian]] | agency=[[Reuters]] | date=July 24, 2015}}</ref>
In October 2015, [[Fernando Haddad]], the mayor of [[São Paulo]], signed a bill to allow for a new category of "black taxis" which would operate in parallel to the city's existing licensed taxis but only be bookable via mobile phone apps. Uber rejected the proposal.<ref>{{cite news | last=Horch | first=Dan | title=Uber Rejects Proposal That Would Legalize Its Service in Brazil's Largest City | url=https://bits.blogs.nytimes.com/2015/10/08/uber-rejects-proposal-that-would-legalize-its-service-in-brazils-largest-city/ | work=[[The New York Times]] | date=October 8, 2015}}{{subscription required}}</ref>
In late 2015, an Uber driver was beaten by taxi drivers in Brazil, and similar attacks followed.<ref>{{cite news | url=https://techcrunch.com/2015/10/01/the-fight-against-uber-is-getting-violent-in-brazil/ | title=The Fight Against Uber is Getting Violent in Brazil | first=Julie | last=Ruvolo | work=[[TechCrunch]] | date=October 1, 2015}}</ref><ref>{{cite news | url=http://agenciabrasil.ebc.com.br/en/geral/noticia/2016-06/brazil-taxi-drivers-angered-uber-attack-family-car | title=Brazil: Taxi drivers attack family in a car mistaken for Uber | first=Paula | last=Laboissière | work=[[Agência Brasil]] | date=June 2, 2016}}</ref>
===Bulgaria=== Uber began operations in [[Sofia]] in December 2014. In September 2015, a court upheld fines imposed on Uber for unfair trade practices and Uber subsequently stopped service in [[Bulgaria]].<ref>{{cite news | title=Uber suspends services in Bulgaria | url=https://sofiaglobe.com/2015/10/06/uber-suspends-services-in-bulgaria/ | work=The Sofia Globe | date=October 6, 2015}}</ref>
===Canada=== Uber drivers in Canada are required "to register, collect and remit HST/GST from their fares to the government", regardless of their income.<ref>{{cite web | title=Uber GST/HST Issue | url=http://barretttaxlaw.com/uber-gsthst-issue/ | publisher=Barrett Tax Law| date=2015-08-17 }}</ref>
====Toronto==== On December 5, 2012, [[Toronto]] officials charged Uber with 25 municipal licensing infractions, including operation of an unlicensed taxi brokerage and unlicensed limousine service.<ref>{{cite news | url=https://www.thestar.com/news/gta/2012/12/05/taxi_app_company_uber_charged_with_licensing_offences.html | title=Taxi app company Uber charged with licensing offences | first=Patty | last=Winsa | work=[[Toronto Star]] | date=December 5, 2012}}</ref> Municipal officials said they had advised the company to comply with local regulations and that rival taxi dispatch apps had obtained licenses.<ref>{{cite news | url=http://torontosun.com/2012/10/18/uber-a-lone-rogue-in-toronto/ | title=Uber: A Lone Rogue in Toronto | first=Jim | last=Bell | work=[[Toronto Sun]] | date=October 18, 2012}}</ref> Despite support from some quarters including [[list of mayors of Toronto|mayor]] [[John Tory]], [[Toronto Police Service]] launched a crackdown on Uber drivers.<ref name=Toronto1>{{cite news | title=Toronto Police launch crackdown on Uber drivers | url=https://www.theglobeandmail.com/news/toronto/toronto-police-launch-crackdown-on-uber-drivers/article23706745/ | last=Hui | first=Ann | work=[[The Globe and Mail]] | date=March 31, 2015}}</ref><ref name="Toronto2">{{cite news | title=Court show looms over Uber's future in Toronto | last=Lu | first=Vanessa | work=[[Toronto Star]] | url=https://www.thestar.com/business/2015/05/29/court-shown-looms-over-ubers-future-in-toronto.html | date=May 29, 2015}}</ref> In July 2015, a $400M class-action lawsuit was filed against UberX and UberXL in [[Toronto]] on behalf of Ontario taxi and limo drivers, brokers, and owners, who alleged that Uber violated section 39.1 of the province's Highway Traffic Act by having unlicensed drivers picking up passengers and transporting them for compensation.<ref>{{cite news | url=https://www.thestar.com/news/gta/2015/07/23/taxi-limo-drivers-launch-400m-class-action-lawsuit-against-uberx-uberxl.html | title=Taxi, limo drivers launch $400M class-action lawsuit against UberX, UberXL | work=[[Toronto Star]] | first=Alyshah | last=Hasham | date=July 23, 2015}}</ref> In March 2016, Sukhvir Tehethi, a local taxi driver, filed an injunction against Uber to stop it from operating.<ref>{{cite news | url=https://toronto.ctvnews.ca/cab-driver-files-injunction-to-stop-uberx-in-toronto-1.2816122 | title=Cab driver files injunction to stop UberX in Toronto | first=Kendra | last=Mangione | work=[[CTV News]] | date=March 14, 2015}}</ref> A Toronto city councillor warned that passengers using UberX may be fined up to $20,000.<ref>{{cite web | last1=Csandy | first1=Ashley | title=Toronto city councillor suggests UberX passengers could be fined up to $20,000 for using 'bandit taxis' | url=https://nationalpost.com/news/toronto/toronto-city-councillor-suggests-uberx-passengers-could-be-fined-up-to-20000-for-using-bandit-taxis | work=[[National Post]] | date=July 14, 2015}}</ref> On March 3, 2016, after hours of heated debate, the City Council of Toronto passed a bylaw allowing UberX to operate legally in the city with conditions, while also cutting regulations for taxis.<ref>{{cite news | title=UberX will be allowed to operate legally in Toronto, city council decides | url=https://www.theglobeandmail.com/news/toronto/divided-toronto-council-seeks-middle-ground-as-uber-debate-begins/article29835110/ | first=Oliver | last=Moore | work=[[The Globe and Mail]] | date=May 3, 2016}}</ref>
====Edmonton==== Edmonton officials unveiled a proposed TNC bylaw on September 9, 2015 to permit Uber to operate legally in Edmonton. Uber opposed the accompanying regulations.<ref>{{cite web | url=https://edmontonsun.com/2015/09/04/edmonton-unveils-bylaw-to-accommodate-uber/wcm/8c037000-ed28-41a9-b5f0-8d09c8316e14 | title=Edmonton unveils bylaw to accommodate Uber | work=[[Edmonton Sun]] | date=September 4, 2015}}</ref><ref>{{cite news | last=Lazzarino | first=Dave | title=Edmonton bylaw would cause Uber operations to cease says GM | url=https://edmontonsun.com/2015/11/13/edmonton-bylaw-would-cause-uber-operations-to-cease-says-gm/wcm/2cd8afb8-0c0c-4ce9-b936-bc1919d42544 | work=[[Edmonton Sun]] | date=November 13, 2015}}</ref> Uber was legalized in Edmonton on Wednesday, January 27, 2016 effective as of March 1, 2016.<ref>{{cite news | url=https://www.cbc.ca/news/canada/edmonton/uber-to-be-legal-in-edmonton-after-city-council-vote-1.3422479 | title=Uber to be legal in Edmonton after city council vote | last=Bellefontaine | first=Michelle | work=[[CBC News]] | date=January 27, 2016}}</ref><ref>{{cite news | url=https://www.thestar.com/news/city_hall/2016/01/28/edmonton-legalizes-uber-paving-way-for-toronto.html | title=Edmonton legalizes Uber, paving way for Toronto | work=[[Toronto Star]] | date=January 28, 2016}}</ref> However, Uber ceased operations in Edmonton on March 1, 2016, citing inability to obtain the necessary insurance.<ref>{{cite news | last1=Osman | first1=Laura | last2=Bellefontaine | first2=Michelle | title=Uber suspends operations in Edmonton over insurance delay | url=http://www.cbc.ca/news/canada/edmonton/uber-suspends-operations-in-edmonton-over-insurance-delay-1.3469425 | website=[[CBC News]] | date=February 29, 2016}}</ref> Uber continued to operate outside of Edmonton despite lack of insurance or proper licensing of their drivers.<ref>{{cite news | last1=Stolte | first1=Elise | title=Uber confirms app will be dead Tuesday in Edmonton because government insurance policy not in place | url=https://edmontonjournal.com/business/local-business/alberta-government-says-uber-insurance-policy-wont-be-ready-for-tuesday-deadline | work=[[Edmonton Journal]] | date=March 1, 2016}}</ref>
====Calgary==== In 2015, [[Calgary, Alberta]] charged at least 17 drivers illegally driving for Uber without insurance.<ref>{{cite news | last=Howell | first=Trevor | title=Sting operation nabs 17 Uber drivers, while taxi committee OKs option to legalize private-for-hire companies | url=https://calgaryherald.com/news/traffic/sting-operation-nabs-17-uber-drivers-while-taxi-committee-oks-option-to-legalize-private-for-hire-companies | work=[[Calgary Herald]] | date=November 11, 2015}}</ref> Uber was given clearance to operate in Calgary in December 2016.<ref>{{cite news | last=Klingbeil | first=Annalise | title=Calgary wants Uber to cover legal, enforcement bill as relaunch nears | url=https://calgaryherald.com/news/local-news/calgary-wants-uber-to-cover-legal-enforcement-bill-before-relaunch | work=[[Calgary Herald]] | date=30 November 2016}}</ref><ref>{{cite news | last=Gilligan | first=Melissa | title=Uber comes back to Calgary: operations resume Dec. 6, 2016 | url=https://globalnews.ca/news/3097604/uber-comes-back-to-calgary-operations-resume-dec-6-2016/ | work=[[Global News]] | date=November 30, 2016}}</ref>
====Quebec==== Uber continues to negotiate with the government of Quebec after the government issued regulations requiring drivers to undergo 35 hours of training and a background check.<ref name=quebec>{{cite news | url=https://www.theverge.com/2017/10/14/16476542/uber-will-remain-canada-quebec-new-rules-effect-training-background-check | title=Uber will remain in Quebec after new rules go into effect | first=Andrew | last=Liptak | work=[[The Verge]] | publisher=[[Vox Media]] | date=October 14, 2017}}</ref>
===Costa Rica=== On August 21, 2015, Uber started operations in Costa Rica and multiple Uber drivers were immediately attacked by taxi drivers.<ref>{{cite news | url=https://www.reuters.com/article/costarica-uber/uber-driver-attacked-and-cars-stopped-during-costa-rica-launch-idUSL1N10Y0LW20150823 | title=Uber driver attacked and cars stopped during Costa Rica launch | first=Enrique | last=Pretel | work=[[Reuters]] | date=August 23, 2015}}</ref>
===China=== In December 2014, in [[Chongqing]], police raided a training session organised by Uber that was attended by more than 20 drivers. In April 2015, Chinese authorities raided the offices of Uber in [[Guangzhou]], [[Guangdong]].<ref>{{cite news | url=https://www.scmp.com/news/china/society/article/1783409/chinese-transport-officials-raid-ubers-guangzhou-office | title=Chinese transport officials raid Uber's Guangzhou office in smartphone taxi-app crackdown | first=Adrian | last=Wan | work=[[South China Morning Post]] | date=May 1, 2015}}</ref>
On May 6, 2015, local police raided Uber's offices in [[Chengdu]], in [[Sichuan]] province.<ref>{{cite news | url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2015/may/07/ubers-operations-under-investigation-in-second-chinese-city | title=Uber's operations under investigation in second Chinese city | work=[[The Guardian]] | date=May 7, 2015}}</ref>
In 2016, Uber sold its Chinese operations to [[DiDi (company)|Didi]].<ref>{{cite news | url=https://www.wsj.com/articles/china-s-didi-chuxing-to-acquire-rival-uber-s-chinese-operations-1470024403 | title=Uber Sells China Operations to Didi Chuxing | first1=Alyssa | last1=Abkowitz | first2=Rick | last2=Carew | work=[[The Wall Street Journal]] | date=August 1, 2016}}{{subscription required}}</ref>
===Croatia=== Before Uber began operations in Croatia, the [[Sustainable Development of Croatia]] party and major taxi service companies were against it, stating that the price of Uber service doesn't compensate the drivers enough for gas, car maintenance, passenger insurance, nor health and retirement insurance for the driver, and Uber prices also don't include VAT nor surtax. In October 2015, Uber initiated service in [[Zagreb]].<ref>{{cite news | title=Uber Available In Zagreb Starting Today | first=Vedran | last=Pavlic | url=https://www.total-croatia-news.com/business/1243-uber-available-in-zagreb-starting-today | work=Total Croatia News | date=October 22, 2015}}</ref> In June 2016, the Uber started operating in [[Split, Croatia]] and [[Dubrovnik]].<ref>{{cite news | title=Uber Launched in Split and Dubrovnik | url=https://www.croatiaweek.com/uber-launched-in-split-and-dubrovnik/ | work=Croatia Week | date=June 3, 2016}}</ref><ref>{{cite news | title=We arrived at the Croatian coast with a weekend of free rides! | url=https://www.uber.com/en-HR/blog/we-arrived-at-the-croatian-coast-with-a-weekend-of-free-rides | work=Uber | date=June 2, 2016}}</ref> In September 2016, a group of taxi drivers attacked a Uber driver who was waiting for a passenger at [[Zagreb Airport]]. The Uber driver canceled the ride before the passenger arrived and drove away, with the attackers following him. The attack was filmed by the victim and reported to the [[Law enforcement in Croatia]].<ref>{{cite news | title=Uber Driver Attacked At Zagreb Airport | url=https://www.total-croatia-news.com/item/14206-uber-driver-attacked-at-zagreb-airport | first=Zedran | last=Pavlic | work=Croatia News | date=September 26, 2016}}</ref>
===Czech Republic=== The biggest protests against Uber in Prague took place in February 2018, when the taxi drivers drove forth and back along the highway. This was repeated for several days.<ref>{{cite news | url=https://www.radio.cz/en/section/news/prague-taxi-drivers-stage-massive-protest-against-undercut-competition | title=Prague Taxi Drivers Stage Massive Protest Against 'Undercut Competition'| first=Chris | last=Johnstone | work=[[Czech Radio]] | date=February 8, 2018}}</ref> Roads in Prague was also occupied by taxi drivers in October 2017 when they protested near the airport.<ref>{{cite news | url=https://www.seattletimes.com/business/prague-taxi-drivers-block-access-to-airport-to-protest-uber/ | title=Prague taxi drivers block access to airport to protest Uber | agency=[[Associated Press]] | publisher=[[The Seattle Times]] | date=October 2, 2017}}</ref> Uber's activity in Brno was preliminarily stopped by the regional court in July 2017, but in October 2017, a higher court canceled the measure.<ref>{{cite news | url=https://www.radio.cz/en/section/business/uber-back-on-the-road-in-brno-as-legal-battle-continues | title=Uber Back On the Road in Brno as Legal Battle Continues | first=Daniela | last=Lazarová | work=[[Czech Radio]] | date=October 28, 2017}}</ref> In March 2018, Uber concluded an agreement with the Czech government. Drivers under this agreement will have to be licensed as taxi drivers.<ref>{{cite news | url=http://www.intellinews.com/uber-reaches-agreement-with-the-czech-government-138071/ | title=Uber reaches agreement with the Czech government | work=[[Business New Europe]] | date=March 12, 2018}}</ref>
===Denmark=== After Uber Black and UberPop were launched in Copenhagen in November 2014, the [[Danish Transport Authority]] filed a complaint accusing Uber of operating illegally.<ref>{{cite news | title=Denmark seeks to block Uber taxi service | url=https://www.sbs.com.au/news/denmark-seeks-to-block-uber-taxi-service | work=[[Special Broadcasting Service]] | date=20 November 2014}}</ref> In January 2015, Denmark's transport minister stated that, although he was not opposed to Uber, the app was "contrary" to Danish law—consumer safety and employee training were identified as the key concerns.<ref>{{cite news | title=Denmark likely to ban ridesharing service Uber | url=https://www.mercurynews.com/2015/01/22/denmark-likely-to-ban-ridesharing-service-uber/ | agency=[[Associated Press]] | publisher=[[The Mercury News]] | date=January 23, 2015}}</ref>
In July 2016, 6 Uber drivers were convicted for offering taxi services without license. Police also charged more than 48 Uber drivers for unlicensed taxi driving.<ref>{{cite news | url=https://www.reuters.com/article/us-uber-denmark/danish-high-court-convicts-fines-uber-driver-for-lacking-taxi-permits-idUSKBN13D1CP | title=Danish high court convicts, fines Uber driver for lacking taxi permits | first=Nikolaj | last=Skydsgaard | work=[[Reuters]] | date=November 18, 2016}}</ref>
On November 18, 2016, the [[Østre Landsret]] ruled that Uber is an illegal taxi service.<ref>{{cite news | url=https://www.thelocal.dk/20161118/danish-high-court-rules-that-uber-is-illegal-taxi-service/ | title=Uber in Denmark's crosshairs after high court ruling | work=[[The Local]] | date=November 18, 2016}}</ref>
Uber shut operations in Denmark in April 2017.<ref>{{cite news | url=https://www.theguardian.com/technology/2017/mar/28/uber-to-shut-down-denmark-operation-over-new-taxi-laws | title=Uber to shut down Denmark operation over new taxi laws | first=Jon | last=Henley | work=[[The Guardian]] | date=March 28, 2017}}</ref>
===Egypt=== After several protests, sit-ins, and violent attacks by taxi operators in 2016<ref>{{cite news | url=https://www.madamasr.com/en/2016/02/04/feature/politics/taxi-drivers-protest-against-uber-other-app-based-car-services/ | title=Taxi drivers protest against Uber, other app-based car services | last=Charbel | first=Jano | work=[[Mada Masr]] | date=February 4, 2016}}</ref><ref>{{cite news | url=http://english.ahram.org.eg/NewsContent/1/64/190482/Egypt/Politics-/Egyptian-taxi-drivers-start-open-ended-sit-in-to-d.aspx | title=Egyptian taxi drivers start open-ended sit-in to demand Uber, Careem shutdown | first=Menna Alaa | last=El-Din | work=Ahram online | date=March 8, 2016}}</ref> and a lawsuit filed in March 2018, the [[Egyptian government]] legalized Uber and [[Careem]] in May 2018. The regulations require the TNCs to pay license fees and share user data with the government.<ref>{{cite news | url=https://www.reuters.com/article/us-egypt-uber/egypt-passes-law-regulating-uber-careem-ride-sharing-services-idUSKBN1I81VG | title=Egypt passes law regulating Uber, Careem ride-sharing services | first=Nashaat | last=Hamdi | work=[[Reuters]] | date=May 7, 2018}}</ref><ref>{{cite news | url=https://www.forbesmiddleeast.com/en/egypt-issues-law-to-regulate-ride-sharing-services-like-uber-and-careem/ | title=Egypt Issues Law To Regulate Ride-Sharing Services Like Uber And Careem | first=Ranju | last=Warrier | work=[[Forbes]] | date=May 8, 2018}}</ref><ref>{{cite news | url=https://www.egyptindependent.com/parliament-passes-law-regulating-uber-careem-work/ | title=Parliament passes law regulating Uber, Careem work | first=Al-Masry | last=Al-Youm | work=[[Egypt Independent]] | date=May 8, 2018}}</ref>
===European Union=== On June 11, 2014, in a concerted action, taxis blocked roads in major European cities in protest against what they perceived as a threat to their livelihoods from TNCs. The cabbies contended that Uber and similar smartphone app-based services have an unfair advantage because they are not subject to the same kinds of fees and regulations placed on taxis.<ref>{{cite news | url=https://www.theguardian.com/politics/2014/jun/11/taxi-drivers-strike-uber-london-live-updates | title=Taxi drivers in European capitals strike over Uber – as it happened | first=Mark | last=Tran | work=[[The Guardian]] | date=June 11, 2014}}</ref><ref>{{cite news | url=https://online.wsj.com/articles/photos-taxis-blockade-european-cities-in-uber-strike-1402495206 | title=Photos: Taxis Blockade European Cities in Uber Strike | work=[[The Wall Street Journal]] | date=June 11, 2014}}{{subscription required}}</ref>
In December 2017, the [[European Court of Justice]] ruled that Uber is a transport company, subject to local transport regulation in [[European Union]] member states, rather than a [[information society]] service as Uber had argued.<ref>{{cite news | url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/business-42423627 | title=Uber is officially a cab firm, says European court | work=[[BBC News]] | date= December 20, 2017}}</ref>
===Finland=== Uber launched UberPop in Helsinki in 2014. In September 2016, the Helsinki Court of Appeal deemed Uber illegal, as the company was did not have a taxi license.<ref>{{cite news | url=https://www.reuters.com/article/us-uber-finland-idUSKCN11R16V | title=Blow for Uber as Finnish court orders two drivers to give up earnings | first1=Jussi | last1=Rosendahl | first2=Tuomas | last2=Forsell | work=[[Reuters]] | date=September 21, 2016}}</ref> Drivers faced criminal prosecution.<ref>{{cite news | url=http://mashable.com/2016/08/16/uber-finland-investigation/ | title=Finland is cracking down on Uber's peer-to-peer operation | first=Emma | last=Hinchliffe | work=[[Mashable]] | date=November 18, 2016}}</ref>
In 2018, Uber was legalized in Finland.<ref>{{cite news | url=https://techcrunch.com/2018/07/04/uber-relaunches-a-licensed-service-in-finland-after-taxi-law-deregulation/ | title=Uber Relaunches-a Licensed Service in finland after taxi law deregulation | first=Natasha | last=Lomas | work=[[TechCrunch]] | date=July 4, 2018}}</ref>
===France=== [[File:Uber drivers on strike at Montparnasse, Paris 3 February 2016 002.jpg|thumb|upright|Uber drivers on strike at Montparnasse, Paris, February 3, 2016]] On January 13, 2014, cab drivers in Paris attacked an Uber driver's car near [[Charles de Gaulle Airport]], protesting competition.<ref>{{cite news | url=https://techcrunch.com/2014/01/13/an-uber-car-was-attacked-near-paris-as-taxi-drivers-protest-against-urban-transportation-startups/ | title=Protesting Taxi Drivers Attack Uber Car Near Paris | work=[[TechCrunch]] | date=January 13, 2014}}</ref>
On October 17, 2014, a court ruled that Uber was illegal and stated that UberPop violated a pre-existent regulation that bans carpooling for profit and fined Uber €100,000.<ref>{{cite news | title=Uber Technologies Fights French Court Ruling | url=https://blogs.wsj.com/law/2014/10/17/uber-technologies-fights-french-court-ruling/ | first=Sam | last=Schechner | work=[[The Wall Street Journal]] | date=October 17, 2014}}{{subscription required}}</ref>
On December 12, 2014, a French court ruled that Uber could not advertise some of its services to the general public in France; if it did so, it would face a $25,000 daily fine.<ref>{{cite news | url=https://bits.blogs.nytimes.com/2014/12/12/paris-court-gives-uber-a-bit-of-good-news/ | title=Uber Avoids Ban in France as Global Legal Battle Spreads | first1=Loure | last1=Fourquet | first2=Mark | last2=Scott | work=[[The New York Times]] | date=December 12, 2014}}{{subscription required}}</ref>
Effective January 1, 2015, UberPop was banned under the provisions of the Thévenoud Law, which requires anyone carrying passengers for hire to be licensed and have insurance.<ref>{{cite news | url=https://www.nytimes.com/2014/12/16/business/international/france-says-it-will-ban-ubers-low-cost-service-in-new-year.html | title=France Says It Will Ban Uber's Low-Cost Service in New Year | first1=David | last1=Jolly | first2=Mark | last2=Scott | work=[[The New York Times]] | date=December 16, 2014}}{{subscription required}}</ref>
By February 23, 2015 about 100 drivers, mostly first-time offenders, had been ticketed.<ref>{{cite news | title=Uber Drivers Face Fines in Paris | url=http://bits.blogs.nytimes.com/2015/02/22/uber-drivers-face-fines-in-paris/ | first1=Laure | last1=Fourquet | first2=Mark | last2=Scott | work=[[The New York Times]] | date=February 22, 2015}}{{subscription required}}</ref>
UberPool remained operational in Paris<ref name="Bra">{{cite news | title=The Future of Uber and Lyft: A Crowded Back Seat | url=https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2015-01-29/uber-lyft-bet-big-on-carpool-services | first=Brad | last=Stone | work=[[Bloomberg Businessweek]] | date=January 30, 2015}}</ref> and continued to aggressively recruit French drivers and passengers.<ref name=2exec>{{cite news | url=http://www.latimes.com/business/la-fi-tn-uber-france-arrests-20150630-story.html | title=2 Uber executives ordered to stand trial in France | agency=[[Associated Press]] | publisher=[[Los Angeles Times]] | date=June 30, 2015}}</ref>
On June 25, 2015, cab drivers in Paris "locked down" Paris in an anti-Uber protest that became increasingly violent.<ref>{{cite news | url=https://techcrunch.com/2015/06/25/french-anti-uber-protest-turns-to-guerrilla-warfare-as-cabbies-burn-cars-attack-uber-drivers/ | title=French Anti-Uber Protest Turns To Guerrilla Warfare As Cabbies Burn Cars, Attack Uber Drivers | work=[[TechCrunch]] | date=June 25, 2015}}</ref><ref>{{cite news | url=https://www.theverge.com/2015/6/25/8844649/french-taxi-driver-protest-uber-pop-paris | title=French taxi drivers lock down Paris in huge anti-Uber protest | first=Amar | last=Toor | publisher=[[Vox Media]] | work=[[The Verge]] | date=June 25, 2015}}</ref> Musician [[Courtney Love]] got caught in the protest and live tweeted as her Uber cab was violently attacked and she and her driver were held hostage.<ref>{{cite news | title=Courtney Love berates Hollande over 'unsafe taxi ride' in Paris | url=https://www.theguardian.com/music/2015/jun/25/courtney-love-berates-hollande-over-unsafe-taxi-ride-in-paris | last=Gani | first=Aisha | work=[[The Guardian]] | date=June 25, 2015}}</ref>
In June 2015, French authorities arrested 2 Uber managers on 6 charges, including "deceptive commercial practices", complicity in instigating an illegal taxi-driving activity, and the illegal stocking of personal information.<ref name=2exec/><ref>{{cite news | url=http://fortune.com/2015/06/29/uber-executives-arrested/ | title=Two Uber executives arrested in France | first=Claire | last=Groden | work=[[Fortune (magazine)|Fortune]] | date=June 29, 2015}}</ref>
On July 5, 2015, Uber suspended UberPop in the face of pressure by the French government while awaiting a court decision.<ref>{{cite news | first=Sam | last=Schechner | title=Uber to Suspend One of Its Main Services in France | url=https://www.wsj.com/articles/uber-to-suspend-one-of-its-main-services-in-france-1435920525 | work=[[The Wall Street Journal]] | date=July 5, 2015}}{{subscription required}}</ref>
On September 22, 2015, France's highest constitutional authority rejected Uber's appeal of a law banning UberPop.<ref>{{cite news | first=Sam | last=Schechner | title=French Constitutional Council Rejects Uber Appeal of Law Banning UberPop | url=https://www.wsj.com/articles/french-constitutional-council-rejects-uber-appeal-of-transport-law-banning-uberpop-1442941357 | work=[[The Wall Street Journal]] | date=September 22, 2015}}{{subscription required}}</ref><ref>{{cite news | url=https://www.thelocal.fr/20150923/uberpop-top-french-court-confirms-ban-on- | title=UberPop: Top French court confirms ban | work=[[The Local]] | date=September 23, 2015}}</ref>
In June 2016, a Paris court fined Uber €800,000, half suspended, for illegally running its UberPop service in 2015.<ref>{{cite news | url=https://www.reuters.com/article/us-france-ubertech-court/french-court-fines-uber-execs-for-illegal-taxi-service-idUSKCN0YV1DQ | title=French court fines Uber, executives for running illegal service | first=Chine | last=Labbe | work=[[Reuters]] | date=June 9, 2016}}</ref>
===Germany=== In early 2014, Berlin authorities ruled against Uber—which operated in the German cities of Berlin, [[Munich]], [[Frankfurt]], [[Hamburg]], and [[Düsseldorf]]—on two occasions following a case filed by the Berlin Taxi Association. The first ruling, delivered by a court in April 2014, deemed Uber's limousine service to be in breach of local legislation, while an August 13, 2014 decision banned the service from operating in Berlin due to safety concerns—the latter decision, which included a €25,000 fine for non-compliance, cited issues pertaining to unregulated vehicles and unqualified drivers who are not properly insured.<ref>{{cite news | title=Berlin Bans Uber, Taxi Drivers Cheer | url=http://www.inc.com/associated-press/berlin-taxi-drivers-hail-citys-uber-ban.html | first=Frank | last=Jordans | agency=[[Associated Press]] | publisher=[[Inc (magazine)|Inc.]] | date=August 14, 2014}}</ref>
On August 28, 2014, a court in Frankfurt issued an immediate cease and desist order against Uber following an appeal from Taxi Deutschland.<ref name="fra-revoke"/> The [[preliminary injunction]] applied to all of Germany<ref>{{cite news | title=Frankfurt court bans Uber taxi services across Germany | url=https://www.reuters.com/article/us-uber-germany-ruling/frankfurt-court-bans-uber-taxi-services-across-germany-idUSKBN0GX0OM20140902 | first=Eric | last=Auchard | work=[[Reuters]] | date=2 September 2014}}</ref> and included a fine of €250,000 per ride for non-compliance.<ref>{{cite news | title=Uber Pulls Out Of Three German Cities After Court Ban Shrinks Driver Pool | url=https://techcrunch.com/2015/11/02/uber-retrenches-in-germany/ | first=Natasha | last=Lomas | work=[[TechCrunch]] | date=November 2, 2015}}</ref><ref name=Kev/> If the injunction was breached, Uber's German-based employees could be jailed for up to 6 months and the company could be fined. UberBLACK was not affected by the ruling.<ref name=liftsban>{{cite news | title=German Court Lifts Ban on Uber Ride Service | url=https://www.nytimes.com/2014/09/17/business/international/uber-ban-in-germany-is-lifted-by-court.html | first1=Mark | last1=Scott | first2=Sarah | last2=Plass| work=[[The New York Times]] | date= September 16, 2014}}{{subscription required}}</ref>
On September 16, 2014, the district court of Frankfurt revoked the preliminary injunction, thereby re-allowing Uber to operate in Germany.<ref name="fra-revoke">{{cite web | title=Uber welcomes today's Frankfurt court decision lifting the injunction brought by taxi incumbents | url=https://www.uber.com/en-DE/newsroom/uber-begrust-die-entscheidung-des-landgerichts-frankfurt-zur-aufhebung-der-einstweiligen-verfugung-gegen-uberpop-3 | date=September 16, 2014}}</ref> The presiding judge wrote that the Taxi Deutschland case "would have had prospects for success", but the case was merely lodged too late, as any case needs to be filed within two months of a service's launch—Uber started in Germany in April 2014, but the case was filed in August 2014.<ref name=liftsban/>Taxi Deutschland appealed the ruling.<ref>{{cite news | url=https://online.wsj.com/articles/court-overturns-ban-on-uberpop-in-germany-1410872575 | title=German Taxi Drivers to Appeal Lifting of Uber Ban | first=Ulrike | last=Dauer | work=[[The Wall Street Journal]] | date=September 16, 2014}}{{subscription required}}</ref>
On March 18, 2015, a Frankfurt district court imposed a nationwide ban on UberPop, claiming that drivers do not have proper licensing and insurance. Each violation of this order would be subject to a €250,000 fine.<ref>{{cite news | title=German court places nationwide ban on Uber | url=http://fortune.com/2015/03/18/german-court-ban-uber/ | work=[[Fortune (magazine)|Fortune]] | date=March 18, 2015}}</ref><ref>{{cite news | title=An Uber Service Is Banned in Germany Again | url=https://www.nytimes.com/2015/03/19/technology/germany-frankfurt-uber-ruling-taxi.html | first=Melissa | last=Eddy | work=[[The New York Times]] | date=March 18, 2015}}{{subscription required}}</ref><ref>{{cite news | title=Uber? Nein! 4 Essential Apps for Surviving Berlin | url=http://www.hollywoodreporter.com/lists/uber-nein-4-essential-apps-surviving-berlin-971079 | first=Scott | last=Roxborough | work=[[The Hollywood Reporter]] | date=February 2, 2017}}</ref><ref name=Kev>{{cite news | title=Uber banned in Germany by Frankfurt court | url=https://www.bbc.com/news/technology-29027803 | first=Kevin | last=Rawlinson | work=[[BBC News]] | date=September 2, 2014}}</ref><ref name="Scott14">{{cite news | title=Court Upholds Ban on Uber in Berlin | first=Mark | last=Scott | url=https://bits.blogs.nytimes.com/2014/09/26/court-upholds-ban-on-uber-in-berlin/ | work=[[The New York Times]] | date=September 26, 2014}}{{subscription required}}</ref>
Uber then limited its operations to its UberX and UberBLACK services, which requires drivers that hold passenger transport licenses.<ref>{{cite news | url=https://www.reuters.com/article/us-uber-germany-cities/uber-germany-retreats-to-berlin-munich-idUSKCN0SO2R620151030 | title=Uber Germany retreats to Berlin, Munich | first=Steven | last=Scheer | work=[[Reuters]] | date=October 30, 2015}}</ref>
===Hong Kong=== On August 11, 2015, [[Hong Kong Police]] raided Uber's office after arresting 5 drivers in a sting operation aimed at combating [[illegal taxis]].<ref>{{cite news | url=http://www.foxnews.com/world/2015/08/11/hong-kong-police-raid-uber-office-after-arresting-5-drivers.html | title=Hong Kong Police Raid Uber Office After Arresting 5 Drivers | agency=[[Associated Press]] | publisher=[[Fox News]] | date=August 11, 2015}}</ref><ref>{{cite news | url=https://www.scmp.com/news/hong-kong/law-crime/article/1848726/five-uber-drivers-arrested-hong-kong-sting-unlicensed-car | title=Five Uber drivers arrested in Hong Kong sting on unlicensed car-hailing services | first=Timmy | last=Sung | work=[[South China Morning Post]] | date=11 August 2015}}</ref> Two more drivers were arrested on the next day. However, the Hong Kong government investment agency, [[InvestHK]], had endorsed Uber as one of its "success stories" on its website, although the endorsement was later removed.<ref>{{cite news | url=https://www.scmp.com/news/hong-kong/economy/article/1848836/uber-success-story-removed-hong-kong-government-investment | title=Uber 'success story' removed from Hong Kong government investment agency website after police raid car-hailing app | first=Danny | last=Lee | work=[[South China Morning Post]] | date=August 12, 2015}}</ref>
On March 15, 2018, a group of local taxi drivers protested outside the [[Hong Kong Police Headquarters]], requesting for actions to be taken on those "unlicensed taxis". They accused Uber from using false and misleading documents to lie to the public.<ref>{{cite news | url=https://www.scmp.com/news/hong-kong/economy/article/2137284/hong-kong-cabbies-hold-protest-against-unlicensed-taxis-uber | title=Hong Kong cabbies hold protest against 'unlicensed taxis' on Uber | first=Su | last=Xinqi | work=[[South China Morning Post]] | date=March 15, 2018}}</ref> On the same day, another group of taxi drivers protested by honking their horns for 30 seconds in [[Admiralty, Hong Kong]] at noon. They also threatened to flood the area with their vehicles if no actions are taken by the government.<ref>{{cite news | url=https://coconuts.co/hongkong/news/taxi-alliance-threatens-flood-central-cabs-protest-uber/ | title=Taxi alliance threatens to flood Central with cabs in protest against Uber | work=coconuts.co | date=March 14, 2018}}</ref>
===Greece=== In April 2018, Uber suspended service in Greece after regulations were implemented that require all rides to begin and end in the fleet partner's designated headquarters or parking area.<ref>{{cite news | url=https://www.reuters.com/article/us-uber-greece/uber-to-suspend-service-in-greece-after-new-legislation-idUSKCN1HC0U0 | title=Uber to suspend service in Greece after new legislation | first=Julia | last=Fioretti | work=[[Reuters]] | date=April 5, 2018}}</ref>
===Hungary=== [[File:Protest against Uber - Budapest, 2016.01.18 (2).JPG|thumb|A protest against Uber by taxi drivers]]
In July 2016, Uber was ruled to be an illegal taxi service in Hungary and subsequently suspended operations.<ref>{{cite news | title=Uber suspends service in Hungary after new law blocks internet access to its dispatchers | url=https://www.theverge.com/2016/7/13/12173228/uber-suspend-hungary-law-block-internet-access-dispatchers | first=Andrew J. | last1=Hawkins | work=[[The Verge]] | publisher=[[Vox Media]] | date=July 13, 2016}}</ref><ref>{{cite news | title=Uber to suspend operations in Hungary due to govt legislation | url=https://www.reuters.com/article/us-uber-hungary-exit/uber-to-suspend-operations-in-hungary-due-to-govt-legislation-idUSKCN0ZT0RS | first1=Krisztina | last1=Than | first2=Krisztina | last2=Fenyo | work=[[Reuters]] | date=July 13, 2016}}</ref>
===India=== ====Hyderabad==== The [[Hyderabad]] road transport authority banned Uber cabs a day after the Indian [[Ministry of Home Affairs (India)|Ministry of Home Affairs]] advised all states to stop the operation of TNCs. A spokesman for the authority said that Uber did not hold a license to operate in the city, and asked the public to cease using Uber.<ref>{{cite news | title=Hyderabad bans Uber cab services after Delhi rape incident | url=https://timesofindia.indiatimes.com/city/hyderabad/Hyderabad-bans-Uber-cab-services-after-Delhi-rape-incident/articleshow/45448527.cms | work=[[The Times of India]] | date=10 December 2014}}</ref>
====Karnataka==== After Home Minister [[Rajnath Singh]] announced in Parliament on December 9, 2014 that he had advised all states and Union territories to ban unregistered and unlicensed cab services, the state [[government of Karnataka]] banned Uber on December 11, 2014.<ref>{{cite news | first=Aaron | last=Pereira | title=Delhi Live: Maharashtra bans all app-based cabs, Karnataka to ban Uber | url=http://www.firstpost.com/india/delhi-live-maharashtra-bans-all-app-based-cabs-karnataka-to-ban-uber-1838045.html | date=11 December 2014}}</ref><ref>{{cite news | title=Now, it's Karnataka's turn to ban Uber | url=http://www.business-standard.com/article/companies/now-it-s-karnataka-s-turn-to-ban-uber-114121100217_1.html | first=Anita | last=Babu | work=[[Business Standard]] | date=12 December 2014}}</ref>
====New Delhi==== In December 2014, following allegations of rape against an Uber driver in [[New Delhi]], Uber was banned from New Delhi for not following the city's compulsory police verification procedure.<ref name="Delhi">{{cite news | url=https://www.hindustantimes.com/delhi-news/delhi-rape-uber-banned-in-capital-accused-driver-sent-to-police-custody-till-dec-11/story-WC1OX5lBAuJPSUKyaZjq5L.html | title=Delhi rape: Uber banned in Capital; accused driver sent to police custody till Dec 11 | first1=Karn Pratap | last1=Singh | first2=Avantika | last2=Mehta | work=[[Hindustan Times]] | date=December 12, 2014}}</ref><ref name=bandelhi>{{cite news | url=https://www.ndtv.com/cheat-sheet/uber-banned-in-delhi-ceo-travis-kalanick-suggests-authorities-partly-to-blame-10-developments-710331 | title=Uber Banned in Delhi, CEO Tries to Dodge Blame: 10 Developments | first=Sonal | last=Mehrotra | work=[[NDTV]] | date=December 8, 2014}}</ref> The driver had been charged, then acquitted, of a prior sexual assault in 2011.<ref name="Delhi"/> Within two days of the rape incident, almost 7,000 people signed a petition calling on Uber to conduct mandatory 7-year background checks on drivers, in line with its U.S. operations.<ref>{{cite news | first=Hannah Jane | last=Parkinson | title=Uber rape scandal: thousands demand driver background checks in India | url=https://www.theguardian.com/technology/2014/dec/08/uber-rape-claim-india-7000-people-sign-petition | work=[[The Guardian]] | date=December 8, 2014}}</ref> Delhi's transport department banned Uber.<ref name=bandelhi/> Uber issued a statement stating that it would work with the Indian government "to establish clear background checks currently absent in their commercial transportation licensing programs."<ref name=bandelhimis/>
In banning Uber, Delhi's transport department cited several rules that Uber had broken. According to New Delhi's Radio Taxi Scheme, 2006, all taxi licensees must be either a company under the Companies Act, 2013 (or the 1956 Act), or a society under the Societies Registration Act, 1860. Furthermore, taxi services must provide adequate parking space for all taxis, as well as sufficiently sized office space to accommodate the control room, the maintenance of a minimum fleet size per license (500 vehicles), and all vehicles must be fitted with GPS/GPRS tracking systems (to be in constant communication with the control room while on duty). The rules also stipulate that the taxi licensee is responsible for ensuring the quality of drivers, including police verifications, supervision, and employee behaviour.<ref name=bandelhimis>{{cite news | url=https://economictimes.indiatimes.com/tech/software/delhi-government-bans-uber-says-it-is-misleading-customers/articleshow/45411180.cms | first=Aman | last=Sharma | title=Delhi Government bans Uber, says it is misleading customers | work=[[The Economic Times]] | date=December 8, 2014}}</ref>
Uber is faced with limits to the number of drivers that are allowed to operate.<ref name=roadblock>{{cite news | url=https://techcrunch.com/2015/09/16/uber-hits-roadblock-in-india-after-being-denied-permission-to-operate-in-delhi/ | title=Uber Hits Roadblock In India After Being Denied Permission To Operate In Delhi | first=Nitish | last=Kulkarni | work=[[TechCrunch]] | date=September 16, 2015}}</ref>but now its operating in New Delhi.
===Indonesia=== On March 22, 2016, thousands of taxi drivers in [[Jakarta]] demonstrated against Uber and a similar service, [[Grab (application)|Grab]]. Several places were targeted during the protests, including the [[Istana Merdeka]], the [[DPR/MPR Building]], and the [[Ministry of Communication and Informatics (Indonesia)|Ministry of Communication and Informatics]] central office. Taxi drivers accused that Grab and Uber were causing them to receive smaller daily incomes due to the rising number of app users. The demonstrators also demanded that the government ban the apps and issue a governmental decree concerning this problem.<ref>{{Cite news | url=https://www.bbc.com/news/world-asia-35868396 | title=Jakarta taxi drivers protest against Uber and Grab | work=[[BBC News]] | date=March 22, 2016}}</ref>
On April 9, 2018, Uber stopped its operations in Indonesia as a result of its merger with Grab.<ref name=grabmerger/>
===Israel=== Uber first introduced a limited service in the [[Tel Aviv]] area in August 2014. However, in November 2017 the Tel Aviv District Court issued a permanent injunction against Uber's utilizing private cars in Israel on the grounds that these lacked the insurance coverage of regulated taxis. Uber was allowed to provide its service in licensed taxis as do other crowd-sourced ride-hailing companies such as [[Gett]]. Although Uber had the support of [[Benjamin Netanyahu|Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu]], the court ruled for the taxi companies and drivers who opposed Uber.<ref>{{cite news | last=Bar-Eli | first=Avi | title=Uber gets taken for a ride in Israel | url=https://www.haaretz.com/israel-news/business/.premium-uber-gets-taken-for-a-ride-in-israel-1.5398978 | agency=[[Haaretz]] | date=February 3, 2016}}{{subscription required}}</ref><ref>{{cite news | last=Schindler | first=Max | title=Court orders Uber to halt private services in Israel in two days | url=https://www.jpost.com/Israel-News/Uber-ordered-by-court-to-halt-services-in-Israel-on-Tuesday-515303 | agency=[[Jerusalem Post]] | date=November 27, 2017}}</ref>
===Italy=== On May 25, 2015, Italian judge dott. Claudio Marangoni banned the UberPop app for unfair competition practices.<ref>{{cite news | url=https://www.thelocal.it/20150526/milan-court-bans-uberpop-banned | title=Milan court bans UberPop app across Italy | work=[[The Local]] | date=May 26, 2015}}</ref><ref>{{cite news | url=https://www.cio.com/article/2926753/italian-court-bans-uberpop-threatens-fine.html | title=Italian court bans UberPop, threatens fine | first=Philip | last=Willan | work=[[CIO magazine]] | date=May 26, 2015}}</ref><ref>{{cite news | url=https://www.thestar.com.my/tech/tech-news/2015/05/27/italian-court-bans-uberpop-car-service/ | title=Italian court bans UberPOP car service | work=[[The Star (Malaysia)|The Star]] | date=May 27, 2015}}</ref>
In February 2017, Italian taxi drivers implemented a [[strike action]].<ref>{{cite news | url=https://www.dw.com/en/italian-taxi-drivers-strike-over-uber-competition/av-37657858 | title=Italian taxi drivers strike over Uber competition | work=[[Deutsche Welle]] | date=February 21, 2017}}</ref><ref>{{cite news | url=https://www.thelocal.it/20170221/taxi-strike-uber-protest-clashes-traffic | title=Traffic chaos and violence as Italian taxi protest rumbles on | work=[[The Local]] | date=21 February 2017}}</ref>
On April 6, 2017, Italian judge dott. Alfredo Landi banned the UberBlack, Uber-Lux, Uber-SUV, Uber-X, Uber-XL, UberSelect and Uber-Van app throughout Italy for unfair competition practices.<ref>{{cite news | | url=https://www.thetimes.co.uk/article/taxi-for-uber-court-rules-that-app-is-unfair-to-italian-cabbies-23620g0nt | title=Taxi for Uber: court rules app is unfair to Italian cabbies | first=Philip | last=Willan | work=[[The Times]] | date=April 10, 2017}}</ref>
In November 2017, Italian taxi drivers implemented another nationwide [[strike action]].<ref>{{cite news | url=https://www.thelocal.it/20171121/italy-taxi-drivers-strike | title=Italy’s taxi drivers on strike nationwide | work=[[The Local]] | date=21 November 2017}}</ref>
===Japan=== In September 2018, Uber struck a deal with the Fuji Taxi Group to let users hail cabs through its app in [[Nagoya]]. Uber initially started with 350 cabs.<ref>{{cite news | url=https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2018-09-06/uber-seals-first-japan-taxi-deal-in-new-pro-regulator-approach?srnd=premium-asia | title=Uber Seals Its First Taxi Deal in Japan | work=[[Bloomberg L.P.]]| date=September 6, 2018}}{{subscription required}}</ref>
===Netherlands=== On December 8, 2014, Dutch judges banned UberPop and implemented a €100,000 fine and the €40,000 fine for drivers who are apprehended. At first Uber continued operating, but Uber shut down its service in November 2015 after office raids by Dutch authorities.<ref>{{cite news | url=https://www.wsj.com/articles/dutch-authorities-raid-uber-office-in-amsterdam-for-second-time-this-year-1443526747 | title=Dutch Authorities Raid Uber Office in Amsterdam for Second Time This Year | first=Archie | last=Van Riemsdijk | work=[[The Wall Street Journal]] | date=September 29, 2015}}{{subscription required}}</ref><ref>{{cite news | url=https://www.wsj.com/articles/uber-to-drop-low-cost-uberpop-car-hailing-service-in-the-netherlands-1447874647 | title=Uber to Drop Low-Cost Uberpop Car-Hailing Service in the Netherlands | first1=Archie | last1=Van Riemsdijk | first2=Simon | last2=Clark | work=[[The Wall Street Journal]] | date=November 18, 2015}}{{subscription required}}</ref>
===Malaysia=== On October 15, 2014, five Uber drivers were involved in a crackdown by the Road Transport Department (JPJ), under the Ops Teksi Uber 2014 operation—which began on October 1. The 4 other vehicles were returned to their respective owners—with their documents confiscated pending further investigation by the Land Public Transport Commission (SPAD). Due to a wide range of circumstances, the 4 vehicles could be returned to owners should proper documents and other factors correlate.<ref>{{cite news | url=http://paultan.org/2014/10/15/uber-drivers-involved-crackdown/ | title=Uber drivers involved in crackdown by JPJ | first=Gregory | last=Sze | work=[[Paultan.org]] | date=October 15, 2014}}</ref> On October 17, 2014, JPJ continued its crackdown on drivers.<ref>{{cite news | url=http://paultan.org/2014/10/17/crackdown-uber-continues-says-jpj/ | title=Crackdown on Uber vehicles to continue, says JPJ | first=Danny | last=Tan | work=[[Paultan.org]] | date=17 October 2014}}</ref> Between October 2014 and October 2015, the Land Public Transport Commission impounded 44 Uber vehicles, using many methods such as tracking the vehicles using Uber's app.<ref>{{cite news | url=http://www.freemalaysiatoday.com/category/nation/2015/10/05/spad-to-take-down-uber-vehicles-with-extreme-prejudice/ | title=SPAD to take down Uber vehicles with extreme prejudice | work=[[Free Malaysia Today]] | date=October 5, 2015}}</ref> It was also reported that some taxi drivers have taken it upon themselves to nab Uber drivers and turn them over to the police.<ref>{{cite news | url=https://paultan.org/2015/10/13/taxi-drivers-told-by-police-they-cannot-take-matters-into-their-own-hands-over-uber-and-grabcar-issue/ | title=Uber-GrabCar issue: Taxi drivers taking law into own hands | first=Anthony | last=Lim | work=[[Paultan.org]] | date=October 13, 2015}}</ref><ref>{{cite news | url=https://www.nst.com.my/news/2015/10/cops-cabbies-stop-%E2%80%98arresting%E2%80%99-uber-drivers | title=Cops to cabbies: Stop 'arresting' Uber drivers | work=[[New Straits Times]] | date=October 9, 2015}}</ref>
In July 2017, legislation was passed to legalize Uber.<ref>{{cite news | url=https://www.reuters.com/article/us-malaysia-transportation/malaysia-legalizes-e-hailing-services-as-grab-uber-compete-idUSKBN1AC1UN | title=Malaysia legalizes e-hailing services as Grab, Uber compete | first=Joseph | last=Sipalan | work=[[Reuters]] | date=July 27, 2017}}</ref><ref>{{cite news | url=https://www.thestar.com.my/news/nation/2017/07/27/e-hailing-services-now-legal-in-malaysia/ | title=Uber, Grab now legal in Malaysia | first=Loshana K. | last=Shagar | work=[[The Star (Malaysia)|The Star]] | date=July 27, 2017}}</ref>
===New Zealand=== In January 2015, several Uber vehicles were stopped by New Zealand police, claiming that Uber was in violation of the Land Transport Act. Two Uber drivers were charged with violating the Land Transport Act and face fines of up to NZ$10,000.<ref>{{cite news | url=https://www.nzherald.co.nz/nz/news/article.cfm?c_id=1&objectid=11384728 | title=Cops pounce on Uber | last=Maas | first=Amy | work=[[The New Zealand Herald]] | date=January 11, 2015}}</ref>
On January 20, 2015, the Associate Transport Minister, [[Craig Foss]], said that the rules covering taxis and private hire services, including Uber, will be reviewed by New Zealand officials by mid-2015.<ref>{{cite news | url=http://www.stuff.co.nz/business/industries/65226952/uber-takes-aim-at-governments-outdated-regulations | title=Government to review taxi rules after Uber campaign | first=Peter | last=Lawry | work=[[Stuff.co.nz]] | date=January 20, 2015}}</ref><ref>{{cite news | url=https://www.nbr.co.nz/article/foss-orders-review-regs-restraining-uber-ng-167528 | title=Foss orders review of regs restraining Uber | work=[[National Business Review]] | date=January 20, 2015}}</ref>
In April and May 2016 the New Zealand Transport Authority (NZTA) sent warnings to 17 Uber drivers who did not comply with current regulations.<ref>{{cite news | url=https://www.stuff.co.nz/business/79938132/nzta-issues-17-official-warnings-to-noncompliant-uber-drivers-with-one-ordered-off-the-road | title=NZTA issues 17 official warnings to non-compliant Uber drivers, with one ordered off the road | work=[[Stuff.co.nz]] | date=May 12, 2016}}</ref>
On August 3, 2017, Uber New Zealand GM, Richard Menzies, announced that Uber is formally recognized as part of the public transport mix, meaning it can legally operate in New Zealand.<ref>{{cite news | url=https://www.uber.com/en-NZ/blog/wellington/rideshare-regulations/ | title=Uber recognised as part of New Zealand’s transport mix! | work=Uber | date=August 4, 2017}}</ref> Uber Eats was later launched in New Zealand that year.
===Norway=== Uber began operations in Norway in 2014.<ref>{{cite news | url=https://www.tu.no/artikler/na-skal-uber-etablere-seg-i-norge/231693 | title=Nå skal Uber etablere seg i Norge | first=Erlend Tangerass | last=Lygre | work=[[Teknisk Ukeblad]] | date=September 22, 2014 | language=Norwegian}}</ref>
According to the Norwegian Professional Transport Act, a taxi license is required to charge for passenger transport "addressed to general public on public space"<ref>{{cite web | url=https://lovdata.no/dokument/NL/lov/2002-06-21-45/KAPITTEL_2 | title=Professional Transport Act §4 | language=Norwegian}}</ref> In 2015, an Uber driver was acquitted because the court found that communication through a [[mobile app]] was not to be regarded as "public space."<ref>{{cite news | url=https://stammen.no/en/innovasjon/selvfolgelig-er-uber-lovlig-i-norge | title=Of course, Uber legal in Norway! | first=Karl | last=Phillip | work=stammen.no | date=December 8, 2015}}</ref>
On October 30, 2017, Uber suspended its UberPOP service in Oslo, continuing to operate UberBLACK and UberXL service.<ref>{{cite news | url=https://www.reuters.com/article/us-uber-norway/uber-suspends-unlicensed-service-in-norway-in-change-of-tack-idUSKBN1CE0BO | title=Uber suspends unlicensed service in Norway in change of tack | first=Julia | last=Fioretti | work=[[Reuters]] | date=October 9, 2017}}</ref><ref>{{cite news | url=https://techcrunch.com/2017/10/09/uber-shutters-uberpop-in-oslo-says-it-hopes-for-law-change/ | title=Uber-shutters uberpop in oslo says it hopes for law change | first=Natasha | last=Lomas | work=[[TechCrunch]] | date=October 9, 2017}}</ref>
===Philippines=== On October 23, 2014, despite the recommendation of the [[Metropolitan Manila Development Authority]],<ref>{{cite news | url=https://www.rappler.com/business/industries/215-tech-biz/72898-ltfrb-uber-sting-operation | title=No franchise: Uber falls in LTFRB sting operation | work=[[Rappler]] | date=October 23, 2014}}</ref> the Philippine [[Land Transportation Franchising and Regulatory Board (Philippines)|Land Transportation Franchising and Regulatory Board]] (LTFRB) imposed a ₱120,000 (US$2,676) to ₱200,000 (US$4,460) fine for the use of the Uber app.<ref name="Manila">{{cite news | url=http://www.gmanetwork.com/news/story/384847/economy/companies/with-fines-of-up-to-p200k-ltfrb-starts-going-after-uber-vehicles|title=With fines of up to P200K, LTFRB starts going after Uber vehicles | first=Andrei | last=Medina | website=[[GMA News]] | date=October 23, 2014}}</ref> A spokesperson for the board said that the fines were issued because Uber did not have an approved franchise to operate in the country.<ref name="Manila" /> The LTFRB also remarked that Uber can still operate in [[Metro Manila]] if the [[House of Representatives of the Philippines]] grants the company a proper legislative franchise.<ref>{{cite news | url=https://news.abs-cbn.com/video/nation/metro-manila/10/30/14/ltfrb-review-uber-operations | title=LTFRB urges Congress to issue legislative franchise to Uber | work=[[ABS-CBNnews.com]] | date=29 October 2014}}</ref>
On October 30, 2014, after an intervention from the [[Department of Transportation and Communications (Philippines)|Department of Transportation and Communications]], the LTFRB temporarily suspended its campaign of apprehending Uber vehicles.<ref>{{cite news | url=http://www.abs-cbnnews.com/video/nation/metro-manila/10/30/14/ltfrb-review-uber-operations | title=LTFRB to review 'Uber' operations | work=[[ABS-CBNnews.com]] | date=31 October 2014}}</ref>
Amid opposition from taxi companies, On May 10, 2015, TNCs gained legal ground to operate, with the country's Department of Transportation and Communications giving them a new classification as The Transportation Network Vehicle Service. The country requires a GPS system installed, a young fleet of vehicles, and the appropriate permits. Taxis were also given a chance to compete by also giving them a sub-classification that matches features found in Uber and other similar services.<ref>{{cite news | url=http://cnnphilippines.com/news/2015/08/13/LTFRB-drafts-guidelines-for-premium-taxi-service-Uber-GrabCar.html | title=LTFRB drafts guidelines for premium taxi operation | work=CNN Philippines | date=August 17, 2015}}</ref> On August 19, 2015, Uber complied and secured government registration to become the country's second TNC after [[Grab (company)|Grab]]]].<ref name=LTFRBapproves>{{cite news | last=Dela Paz | first=Chrisee | title=LTFRB approves Uber as transport network company | url=https://www.rappler.com/business/industries/208-infrastructure/103061-ltfrb-approves-uber-accreditation | work=[[Rappler]] | date=August 19, 2015}}</ref> Individual vehicle operators however still need to undergo separate registrations with the LTFRB.<ref name=LTFRBapproves/>
The service was suspended for a month on August 14, 2017 due to the defiance of LTFRB's order on not to accredit drivers in their systems starting July 26, 2017.<ref>{{cite news | url=https://www.rappler.com/nation/178706-ltfrb-suspends-uber | title=Uber suspended for 1 month | first=Rambo | last=Talabong | work=[[Rappler]] | date=August 14, 2017}}</ref>
===Poland=== Following the commencement of Uber services in [[Warsaw]] in 2014, Jaroslaw Iglikowski, chief of the Union of Warsaw Taxi Drivers, said: "We will put pressure on politicians, and demand that they change the regulations [for firms offering taxi services]."<ref name="War">{{cite news | title=Uber taxi giant takes on Poland | url=http://www.thenews.pl/1/12/Artykul/179221,Uber-taxi-giant-takes-on-Poland | work=PolskieRadio.pl | date=19 August 2014}}</ref>
In 2015, following protests by taxi drivers, laws were modified so that Uber drivers do not enjoy a regulatory advantage over taxi drivers.<ref>{{cite news | url=http://wbj.pl/poland-to-change-regulation-for-uber/ | title=Poland to change regulation for Uber | first=Wojciech | last=Rylukowski | work=[[Warsaw Business Journal]] | date=July 2, 2015}}</ref>
In June 2017, after a protest by 2,000 taxi drivers, Deputy Prime Minister [[Mateusz Morawiecki]] announced that Poland may impose more regulations on Uber.<ref>{{cite news | url=https://www.reuters.com/article/us-uber-poland-regulations/poland-may-impose-more-regulations-on-uber-idUSKBN19516P | title=Poland to change regulation for Uber | first=Marcin | last=Goclowsk | work=[[Reuters]] | date=June 14, 2017}}</ref><ref>{{cite news | url=https://www.bostonglobe.com/business/2017/06/05/polish-taxi-drivers-are-latest-group-taking-uber/I28fEY4n7NH3C6GhsBBzCP/story.html | title=Polish taxi drivers are the latest group taking on Uber | first=Monika | last=Scislowska | agency=[[Associated Press]] | publisher=[[The Boston Globe]] | date=June 5, 2017}}</ref>
===Portugal=== On April 29, 2016, a protest including 2,000 taxi drivers took place in major cities in Portugal.<ref>{{cite news | url=https://www.dw.com/en/lisbon-taxi-drivers-uber-protest-brings-traffic-to-a-crawl/a-19225926 | title=Lisbon taxi drivers' Uber protest brings traffic to a crawl | work=[[Deutsche Welle]] | date=April 29, 2016}}</ref> In December 2017, Uber was ruled to be illegal in Portugal.<ref>{{cite news | url=http://www.theportugalnews.com/news/uber-declared-illegal-in-portugal/44111 | title=Uber declared illegal in Portugal | work=[[The Portugal News]] | date=December 6, 2017}}</ref>
===Romania=== In May 2015, the Romanian Parliament adopted a law which banned transport services by unauthorized drivers, effectively making Uber illegal; however, Uber continues to operate in Romania as it battles in the courts.<ref>{{cite news | url=http://www.business-review.eu/news/uber-launches-in-third-romanian-city-brasov-after-bucharest-and-cluj-napoca-124503 | title=Uber launches in third Romanian city: Brasov, after Bucharest and Cluj-Napoca | work=Business Review | date=November 17, 2016}}</ref>
===Saudi Arabia=== In March 2017, Saudi Arabia banned Uber and [[Careem]] from picking up at the airport, citing license requirements. Saudi Arabia had earlier banned the TNCs from allowing non-Saudis to register as drivers.<ref>{{Cite news | url=https://www.reuters.com/article/us-saudi-regulations-ride-share/uber-and-careem-banned-from-airport-pickups-in-saudi-arabia-idUSKBN16921F | title=Uber and Careem banned from airport pickups in Saudi Arabia | first=Katie | last=Paul | work=[[Reuters]] | date=March 2, 2017}}</ref>
===Singapore=== On February 10, 2017, the Singapore [[Land Transport Authority]] (LTA)ruled that private hire cars who used Uber or [[Grab (company)|Grab]] service are not exempted from the child seat requirement. For safety reasons, all vehicles in Singapore must have booster seats or child restraints for passengers under 1.35m in height.<ref>{{cite web | url=https://www.lta.gov.sg/apps/news/page.aspx?c=3&id=bcfb0de5-1ea0-49bc-bcc2-2d5639044174 | title=Private Hire Cars Not Exempt From Child Seat Requirement | publisher=[[Land Transport Authority]] | date=February 10, 2017}}</ref>
In March 2017, LTA introduced a new regulation for private hire cars called Private Hire Car Driver's Vocational Licence (PDVL) which took effect in July 2017.<ref>{{cite web | url=https://www.lta.gov.sg/apps/news/page.aspx?c=2&id=f1dae5f8-c9b5-4930-98d9-2eef544d9de9 | title=Applications For Private Hire Car Drivers' Vocational Licence To Open On 13 March 2017}}</ref> This is to ensure that commuter's interest is better protected.<ref>{{cite web | url=https://www.lta.gov.sg/apps/news/page.aspx?c=2&id=59c466e2-8eff-46bc-8d60-f13bb00de4b2 | title=New Regulations For Private Hire Car Drivers And Vehicles To Better Protect Commuter Interests}}</ref>
In April 2018, Uber shut down services in Singapore as a result of its merger with [[Grab (company)|Grab]].<ref name=grabmerger>{{cite press release | url=https://www.grab.com/sg/press/business/grab-merges-with-uber-in-southeast-asia/ | title=Grab Merges with Uber in Southeast Asia | publisher=[[Grab (company)|Grab]] | date=March 26, 2018}}</ref>
===South Africa=== Over 300 vehicles operating for the Uber service in [[Cape Town]] were impounded in 2015. Local transport officials claimed that the service was operating without suitable permits.<ref>{{cite news | url=https://www.news24.com/MoveMag/Archive/cape-town-clamps-down-on-uber-impounds-300-cars-20170728 | title=Cape Town clamps down on Uber, impounds 300 cars | author=Faeza | work=[[News24]] | date=July 18, 2016}}</ref>
In Cape Town, on June 3, 2016, metered taxi drivers blockaded the road to the city's airport and forced passengers out of vehicles whilst attacking Uber drivers.<ref>{{cite news | url=https://www.news24.com/SouthAfrica/News/meter-taxi-drivers-take-on-uber-drivers-at-ct-airport-20160603 | title=Meter taxi drivers take on Uber drivers at CT airport | first=Kimon | last=de Greef | work=[[News24]] | date=June 3, 2016}}</ref>
In July 2018, in Johannesburg, Uber and taxi drivers initiated a [[strike action]], blocking roads and, in 3 cases, taking the hones of drivers that did not participate in the strike.<ref>{{cite news | url=https://www.timeslive.co.za/news/south-africa/2018-07-03-beware-catching-an-uber-ride-today-as-drivers-embark-on-strike/ | title=Beware catching an Uber ride today as drivers embark on strike | work=[[The Times (South Africa)|The Times]] | date=July 3, 2018}}</ref>
In August 2018, Uber opposed a new law that would prohibit the company for allowing drivers to operate without a license, subject to a fine up up to R100,000, claiming that many drivers were facing delays in getting permits from government agencies.<ref>{{cite news | url=https://www.iol.co.za/motoring/industry-news/new-law-could-cost-thousands-of-drivers-their-jobs-uber-16651107 | title=New law could cost thousands of drivers their jobs – Uber | work=[[Independent Online (South Africa)|Independent Online]] | date=August 20, 2018}}</ref>
===South Korea=== The [[Seoul]] city government released an official statement in July 2014 expressing its intention to ban Uber. The government stated that South Korean law prohibits fee-paying transport services that use unregistered private or rented vehicles, and a Seoul driver received a one-million won (US$974) fine in April 2014 after using Uber to solicit customers in a rented car. The city government also initiated a police investigation of Uber in June 2014, but the request was suspended due to a lack of evidence; however, the July statement indicated that the investigation would be recommenced.<ref>{{cite news | url=https://blogs.wsj.com/korearealtime/2014/07/21/seoul-moves-to-ban-uber-plans-own-app/ | title=Seoul Moves to Ban Uber, Plans Own App | first=Jeyup S. | last=Kwaak | work=[[The Wall Street Journal]] | date= July 21, 2014}}{{subscription required}}</ref>
In December 2014, Uber announced that the Seoul Central District Prosecutors' Office had issued an [[indictment]] against both the company and Kalanick in regard to the violation of a Korean law prohibiting individuals or firms without appropriate license from providing or facilitating transportation services.<ref>{{cite news | url=https://uk.reuters.com/article/uk-southkorea-uber/south-korea-indicts-uber-ceo-local-unit-for-transport-law-breach-idUKKBN0K20G320141224 | title=South Korea indicts Uber CEO, local unit for transport law breach | first=Se | last=Young Lee | work=[[Reuters]] | date= December 24, 2014}}</ref>
In March 2015, Uber suspended its UberX service in Korea after disputes with officials.<ref>{{cite news | url=https://www.theverge.com/2015/3/6/8160695/uber-south-korea-suspended-seoul | title=Uber suspends UberX services in South Korea – but promises to return | first=James | last=Vincent | work=[[The Verge]] | publisher=[[Vox Media]] | date=March 6, 2015}}</ref>
===Spain=== On December 9, 2014, In the absence of any legal provision for private hire, a judge ordered Uber to cease all activities in Spain. In a statement after the ruling, the Spanish court stated that drivers "lack the administrative authorisation to carry out the job, and the activity they carry out constitutes unfair competition."<ref>{{cite news | title=Uber taxi app banned in Spain | url=https://www.bbc.com/news/business-30395093 | work=[[BBC News]] | date=December 9, 2014}}</ref> The company suspended its operations in Spain on December 30, 2014.<ref>{{cite news | url=https://techcrunch.com/2014/12/30/fiz-pop-ban/ | title=Uber Suspends Its Uber Pop Ride-Sharing Service In Spain Following A Court Ruling | first=Jon | last=Russell | work=[[TechCrunch]] | date=December 30, 2014}}</ref><ref>{{cite news | url=https://bits.blogs.nytimes.com/2014/12/31/uber-suspends-operations-in-spain/ | title=Uber Suspends Operations in Spain | first=Mark | last=Scott | work=[[The New York Times]] | date=December 31, 2014}}{{subscription required}}</ref><ref>{{cite news | url=http://time.com/3651094/uber-pop-spain/ | title=Uber Hits a Speed Bump in Spain | first=Elina | last=Dockterman | work=[[Time (magazine)|Time]] | date=December 31, 2014}}</ref>
Uber restarted operations in Spain in March 2016, this time using only licensed drivers.<ref>{{cite news | url=https://venturebeat.com/2016/03/30/uber-rolls-back-into-spain-with-uberx-licensed-cab-service-in-madrid-and-a-fresh-attitude/ | title=Uber rolls back into Spain with UberX licensed cab service in Madrid and a fresh attitude | first=Paul | last=Sawers | work=[[VentureBeat]] | date=March 30, 2016}}</ref><ref>{{cite news | url=https://www.reuters.com/article/us-spain-uber-tech/uber-returns-to-spanish-streets-in-search-of-regulatory-u-turn-idUSKCN0WW0AO | title=Uber returns to Spanish streets in search of regulatory U-turn | first=Maria | last=Vega Paul | work=[[Reuters]] | date=March 30, 2016}}</ref>
===Switzerland=== In March 2018, the [[Federal Department of Economic Affairs, Education and Research]], gave the legal opinion that under the conditions that bind drivers to Uber that they should be classified as employees.<ref>{{cite news | title=Swiss authorities say Uber drivers should be treated as 'employees' | url=https://www.swissinfo.ch/eng/wage-dumping-_swiss-authorities-say-uber-drivers-should-be-treated-as--employees-/43984356 | work=[[Swissinfo]] | date=March 19, 2018}}</ref>
===Taiwan=== As of December 6, 2014, Uber [[Taiwan]] had received over [[New Taiwan dollar|NT$]]1,000,000 in fines for operating illegally, including a cease and desist of the app, on December 5, 2014. Issues included failure to insure vehicles, operating like a business without a business license, metered fares unknown to passengers, metered fares not inspected by the [[Ministry of Transportation and Communications (Taiwan)|Ministry of Transportation and Communication]], and failure to report income and pay taxes. Many drivers had their licenses suspended for violations.<ref>{{cite news | url=https://chinapost.nownews.com/20141206-63759 | title=MOTC to pull Uber from local app stores | first=Queena | last=Yen | work=[[The China Post]] | date=December 6, 2014}}</ref> In December 2014, the Ministry of Transportation and Communications announced that the company was operating unlicensed taxis in violation of national law, and that the government was considering blocking the service.<ref>{{cite news | url=http://www.straitstimes.com/asia/east-asia/taiwan-says-uber-violating-law-by-operating-without-licence | title=Taiwan says Uber 'violating law' by operating without licence | agency=[[Reuters]] | publisher=[[The Straits Times]] | date=December 22, 2014}}</ref>
Uber was fined 231 million Taiwan dollars ($7.4 million) over two weeks after new rules introduced on January 6, 2017. On February 2, 2017, Uber announced it will suspend its service in Taiwan after the fines.<ref>{{cite news | url=http://fortune.com/2017/02/02/uber-suspend-service-taiwan-fines/ | title=Uber Will Suspend Service in Taiwan After Being Slapped With Over $10 Million in Fines | agency=[[Reuters]] | publisher=[[Fortune (magazine)|Fortune]] | date=February 2, 2017}}</ref><ref>{{cite news | url=https://money.cnn.com/2017/02/02/technology/uber-taiwan-suspending-service-fines/ | title=Uber is suspending its service in Taiwan after being hit with millions of dollars in fines by the government | first1=Jethro | last1=Mullen | first2=Yuli | last2=Yang | work=[[CNN]] | date=February 2, 2017}}</ref>
In April 2017, Uber restarted service in Taiwan.<ref>{{cite news | url=https://mashable.com/2017/04/13/uber-taiwan-returns/ | title=Uber is back in action in Taipei, but there's a big barrier for drivers now | first=Yvette | last=Tan | work=[[Mashable]] | date=April 13, 2017}}</ref><ref>{{cite news | url=https://www.reuters.com/article/us-uber-tech-taiwan/uber-resumes-ride-hailing-service-in-taiwan-after-talks-with-authorities-idUSKBN17F0KB | title=Uber resumes ride-hailing service in Taiwan after talks with authorities | first=J.R. | last=Wu | work=[[Reuters]] | date=April 13, 2017}}</ref>
===Turkey=== On June 2, 2018, following pressure from Istanbul taxi drivers, President [[Recep Tayyip Erdoğan]] said that [[Uber]] is finished in Turkey.<ref>{{cite news | url=https://www.reuters.com/article/us-turkey-uber/ubers-business-is-finished-in-turkey-erdogan-says-idUSKCN1IY0FI | title=Uber's 'business is finished' in Turkey, Erdogan says | first=Ezgi | last=Erkoyun | work=[[Reuters]] | date=June 2, 2018}}</ref><ref>{{cite news | url=https://www.independent.co.uk/news/business/news/uber-taxi-drivers-tayyip-erdogan-istanbul-a8380566.html | title=Uber 'finished' in Turkey, Erdogan says as president moves to ban taxi hailing app| work=[[The Independent]] | date=June 2, 2018}}</ref>
===Thailand=== Following concerns raised by taxi drivers in [[Thailand]] over Uber's lower rates, Uber was declared illegal on November 28, 2014 under Thailand's Motor Vehicle Act B.E. 2522, claiming that Uber vehicles are not properly registered in Thailand, Thai Uber drivers are not properly licensed, and that Uber discriminates against people who do not possess credit cards. Following the announcement, Uber drivers faced a maximum 4,000-baht fine if caught by police.<ref>{{cite news | url=https://www.bangkokpost.com/news/general/445978/uber-declared-illegal-in-thailand-drivers-face-heavy-fines | title=Uber declared illegal in Thailand | work=[[Bangkok Post]] | date=November 28, 2014}}</ref>
In March 2016, Uber was forced to shut its motor bike taxi service.<ref>{{cite news | url=https://www.reuters.com/article/us-thailand-motorbike-taxis-idUSKCN0Y81IH | title=Thailand orders halt to Uber, Grab motorbike taxi service | first=Pairat | last=Temphairojana | work=[[Reuters]] | date=May 17, 2016}}</ref>
In April 2018, Uber shut down its operations in Thailand as a result of its merger with [[Grab (company)|Grab]].<ref name=grabmerger/>
===United Arab Emirates=== ====Dubai==== In January 2017, after a long spat with regulators, Uber signed an agreement with the [[Roads and Transport Authority (Dubai)|Roads and Transport Authority]] of [[Dubai]]. Under this deal, Uber is entitled to deploy about 14,000 vehicles around the city.<ref>{{cite news | url=https://www.reuters.com/article/us-emirates-uber/uber-signs-deal-with-dubai-regulator-after-pricing-rows-idUSKBN14V1GH | title=Uber signs deal with Dubai regulator after pricing rows | first=Celine | last=Aswad | work=[[Reuters]] | date=January 11, 2017}}</ref>
===United Kingdom=== On October 28, 2016, in the case of ''[[Aslam v Uber BV]]'', the Central London [[Employment tribunal]] ruled that Uber drivers are "workers", rather than [[self-employed]] individuals, and are entitled to the minimum wage under the [[National Minimum Wage Act 1998]], paid holiday, and other normal worker entitlements.<ref>{{cite news | url=https://qz.com/822104/the-london-employment-tribunal-rules-uber-drivers-have-workers-rights-in-europes-employment-case-of-the-decade/ | title=A British court rules Uber drivers have workers' rights in the "employment case of the decade" | last=Griswold | first=Alison | work=[[Quartz (publication)|Quartz]] | date=October 28, 2016}}</ref> Two Uber drivers had brought the test case to the employment tribunal with the assistance of the [[GMB Union]], on behalf of a group of drivers in London. Uber appealed the decision.Two Uber drivers had brought the case to the employment tribunal with the assistance of the [[GMB Union]] on 20 July 2016.<ref>{{cite news | url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-37796786 |title=Drivers and campaigners hail Uber employment ruling | work=[[BBC News]] | date=28 October 2016}}</ref><ref>{{cite news | url=https://www.theguardian.com/technology/2016/oct/28/uber-ruling-is-a-massive-boost-for-a-fairer-jobs-market | title=Uber ruling is a massive boost for a fairer jobs market | first=Aditya | last=Chakrabortty | work=[[The Guardian]] | date=October 28, 2016}}</ref><ref>{{cite report | url=https://www.judiciary.gov.uk/wp-content/uploads/2016/10/aslam-and-farrar-v-uber-reasons-20161028.pdf | title=Between (1) Mr Y Aslam (2) Mr J Farrar & Others and (1) Uber B.V. (2) Uber London Ltd (3) Uber Britannia Ltd | publisher=Employment Tribunals | id=Case Nos: 2202550/2015 & Others | date=28 October 2016}}</ref><ref>{{cite news | url=https://uk.reuters.com/article/uk-uber-britain-tribunal/uk-tribunal-rules-uber-drivers-deserve-workers-rights-idUKKCN12S1MT | title=UK tribunal rules Uber drivers deserve workers' rights | first=Costas | last=Pitas | work=[[Reuters]] | date=October 18, 2016}}</ref><ref name=classify>{{cite news | url=https://www.theguardian.com/technology/2016/oct/28/uber-uk-tribunal-self-employed-status | title=Uber loses right to classify UK drivers as self-employed | first=Hilary | last=Osborne | work=[[The Guardian]] | date=October 28, 2016}}</ref><ref>{{cite news | url=https://www.ft.com/content/a0bb02b2-9d0a-11e6-a6e4-8b8e77dd083a | title=Uber drivers win UK legal battle for workers' rights | first1=Jane | last1=Croft | first2=Madhumita | last2=Murgia | work=[[Financial Times]] | date=October 28, 2016}}</ref> On November 10, the court upheld the ruling against Uber's appeal, although the company announced it would launch a new appeal.<ref>{{cite news | url=https://www.theguardian.com/technology/2017/nov/10/uber-loses-appeal-employment-rights-workers | title=Uber loses appeal in UK employment rights case | first=Rob | last=Davies | work=[[The Guardian]] | date=November 10, 2017 | issn=0261-3077}}</ref><ref>{{cite news | url=https://techcrunch.com/2017/11/10/uber-loses-uk-tribunal-appeal-over-driver-employment-rights/ | title=Uber loses uk tribunal appeal over driver employment rights | first=Natasha | last=Lomas | work=[[TechCrunch]] | date=November 10, 2017}}</ref>
====London==== On 11 June 2014, London-based [[Hackney carriage]] (black cab) drivers, members of the Licensed Taxi Drivers Association, disrupted traffic as a protest against [[Transport for London]]'s refusal to stop Uber's calculation of fares based on distance and time taken, as they claimed it infringes upon their right to be the sole users of [[taximeter]]s in London.<ref>{{cite news | url=https://www.bbc.com/news/technology-27317164 | last1=Lee | first1=Dave | last2=Kelion | first2=Leo | title=London black taxis plan congestion chaos to block Uber | work=[[BBC News]] | date=May 8, 2014}}</ref> The following week, London mayor [[Boris Johnson]] stated it would be "difficult" for him to ban Uber "without the risk of a judicial review"; however, he expressed sympathy for the view of the black-cab drivers.<ref name="Alex">{{cite news | title=Boris Johnson says Uber ban in London would be 'difficult' | url=https://www.theguardian.com/technology/2014/jun/16/boris-johnson-uber-ban-london | first=Alex | last=Hern | work=[[The Guardian]] | date=June 16, 2014}}</ref> On October 16, 2015, after Transport for London brought a case to the [[High Court of Justice]] to determine whether the way Uber's app calculates a fare falls under the definition of a taximeter, it was ruled that the app is legal in London.<ref>{{cite news | url=https://www.theguardian.com/technology/2015/oct/16/uber-wins-high-court-case-taxi-app-tfl|title=Uber wins high court case over taxi app | first1=Gwyn | last1=Topham | first2=David | last2=Hellier | first3=Aisha | last3=Gani | work=[[The Guardian]] | date=October 16, 2015}}</ref>
On September 22, 2017 Transport for London announced that it would not renew the license of Uber's local service provider, which was due to expire at the end of that month. Transport for London declared that Uber London Limited was not "fit and proper" to hold a private hire operator license, citing concerns over the company's approach to reporting serious criminal offences, obtaining medical certificates and [[Disclosure and Barring Service]] checks, and the use of [[Greyball]]. Uber indicated that it would appeal the decision.<ref>{{cite news | url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-england-41358640|title=Uber London loses licence to operate | work=[[BBC News]] |date=September 22, 2017}}</ref><ref>{{cite web | url=https://tfl.gov.uk/info-for/media/press-releases/2017/september/licensing-decision-on-uber-london-limited?intcmp=50167 | title=Licensing decision on Uber London Limited | publisher=[[Transport for London]] | date=September 22, 2017}}</ref><ref>{{cite web | url=https://www.londonreconnections.com/2017/understanding-uber-not-app/ | title=Understanding Uber: It's Not About The App | first=John | last=Bull | publisher=London Reconnections | date=September 25, 2017}}</ref> On June 26, 2018 [[Westminster Magistrates' Court]] granted a license for 15 months with additional conditions. Uber had applied for a 5-year license.<ref>{{cite news | url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/business-44612837 | title=Uber overturns ban on operating in London | work=[[BBC News]] | date=June 26, 2018}}</ref>
====York==== On December 12, 2017 York's Gambling, Licensing & Regulatory Committee voted to deny the renewal of Uber's license due to a data breach in 2016 and several complaints against the company and drivers. Uber appealed with QC Philip Kolvin, taking City of York Council to the Magistrates.<ref>{{cite news | url=https://www.reuters.com/article/us-uber-britain-york/uber-submits-appeal-to-keep-operating-in-northern-uk-city-of-york-idUSKBN1ET20J | title=Uber submits appeal to keep operating in northern UK city of York | first=Costas | last=Pitas | work=[[Reuters]] | date=January 4, 2018}}</ref>
Uber withdrew from the appeal on March 14, 2018 with the plan to reapply for the license.<ref>{{cite news | url=https://www.minsterfm.com/news/local/2527818/updated----uber-in-york-withdraws-appeal/ | title=Uber in York withdraws appeal | work=[[Minster FM]] | date=March 14, 2018}}</ref>
