====Brighton and Hove==== On May 1, 2018, [[Brighton and Hove City Council]]'s licensing panel refused to renew Uber's private hire operator license in the city. It cited "significant concerns" about the car hailing app's data breach in 2016, and whether the company was adhering to its commitment to use only Brighton and Hove licensed drivers in the city. Uber said it would appeal.<ref>{{cite news | url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-england-sussex-43965393 | title=Uber licence renewal in Brighton turned down| work=[[BBC News]] | date=May 1, 2018}}</ref>
===United States=== ====Federal==== =====Criminal probe due to use of Greyball===== Uber developed an internal software tool called [[Greyball]], which uses data collected from the Uber mobile app other means, to avoid giving rides to certain individuals. The tool was used starting in 2014. By showing "ghost cars" driven by fake drivers to the targeted individuals in the Uber mobile app, and by giving real drivers a means to cancel rides requested by those individuals, Uber was able to avoid giving rides to known law enforcement officers in areas where its service is illegal. [[Investigative journalism]] by ''[[The New York Times]]'' and the resulting report, published on March 3, 2017, made public Uber's use of Greyball since 2014, describing it as a way to evade city code enforcement officials in [[Portland, Oregon]], Australia, South Korea, and China.<ref name=nyt_greyball>{{cite news | url=https://www.nytimes.com/2017/03/03/technology/uber-greyball-program-evade-authorities.html | first=Mike | last=Isaac | title=How Uber Deceives the Authorities Worldwide | work=[[The New York Times]] | date=March 3, 2017}}</ref> At first, in response to the report, Uber stated that Greyball was designed to deny rides to users who violate Uber's [[terms of service]], including those involved in [[sting operation]]s.<ref name=nyt_greyball/><ref>{{cite news | url=http://www.chicagotribune.com/bluesky/technology/ct-uber-greyball-20170303-story.html | title=Uber's secret 'Greyball' program shows just how far it will go to get its way | first1=Craig | last1=Timberg | first2=Brian | last2=Fung | work=[[Chicago Tribune]] | date=March 3, 2017}}{{subscription required}}</ref> According to Uber, Greyball can "hide the standard city app view for individual riders, enabling Uber to show that same rider a different version". Uber reportedly used Greyball to identify government officials through factors such as whether a user frequently opens the app near government offices, a review of social media profiles by Uber employees to identify law enforcement personnel, and the credit cards associated with the Uber account.<ref name=nyt_greyball/>
On March 8, 2017, Uber admitted that it had used Greyball to thwart government regulators and pledged to stop using the service for that purpose.<ref>{{cite news | first1=Marco | last1=della Cava | website=[[USA Today]]| url=https://www.usatoday.com/story/tech/talkingtech/2017/03/08/uber-stop-using-greyball-target-regulators/98930282/ | title=Uber admits its ghost driver 'Greyball' tool was used to thwart regulators, vows to stop | date=March 8, 2017}}</ref><ref>{{cite news| url=https://newsroom.uber.com/an-update-on-greyballing/ | title=An update on "greyballing" | last=Sullivan | first=Joe | date=March 8, 2017 | publisher=Uber}}</ref>
In May 2017, the [[United States Department of Justice]] opened a criminal investigation into Uber's use of Greyball to avoid local law enforcement operations.<ref>{{cite news | url=https://www.reuters.com/article/us-uber-tech-crime-exclusive/exclusive-uber-faces-criminal-probe-over-software-used-to-evade-authorities-idUSKBN1802U1 | title=Exclusive: Uber faces criminal probe over software used to evade authorities | first1=Dan | last1=Levine | first2=Joseph | last2=Menn | work=[[Reuters]] | date=May 5, 2017}}</ref><ref>{{cite news | url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/news/the-switch/wp/2017/05/04/justice-department-opens-criminal-probe-into-uber/ | title=Justice Department opens criminal probe into Uber | first1=Elizabeth | last1=Dwoskin | first2=Craig | last2=Timberg | work=[[The Washington Post]] | date=May 4, 2017}}</ref><ref>{{cite news | url=https://www.nytimes.com/2017/05/04/technology/uber-federal-inquiry-software-greyball.html | title=Uber Faces Federal Inquiry Over Use of Greyball Tool to Evade Authorities | first=Mike | last=Isaac | work=[[The New York Times]] | date=May 4, 2017}}{{subscription required}}</ref><ref>{{cite news | last=Farivar | first=Cyrus | title=DOJ confirms new criminal probe linked to Waymo v. Uber lawsuit | url=https://arstechnica.com/tech-policy/2017/12/doj-confirms-new-criminal-probe-linked-to-waymo-v-uber-lawsuit/ | work=[[Ars Technica]] | date=December 14, 2017}}</ref>
=====Treatment of drivers as independent contractors===== The [[United States Department of Labor]] issued guidelines in July 2015 to deal with, what it considers, "misclassification" of workers. It argues that any "worker who is 'economically dependent' on the employer should be treated as an employee. By contrast, a worker must be in business for himself or herself to be an independent contractor."<ref name=inc20150515/> The guideline was non-binding, but is expected to have some influence in various court cases which may establish new [[common law]] on the issue.<ref name=inc20150515>{{cite news | title=Labor Department Tries to Clarify Hiring Rules for Gig Economy | url=https://www.inc.com/associated-press/new-guidance-labor-department-employees-contractors.html | last=Rugabar | first=Christopher S. | agency=[[Associated Press]] | publisher=[[Inc. (magazine)|Inc.]] | date=July 15, 2015}}</ref><ref>{{cite news | title=Sharing Economy Companies Sharing the Heat in Contractor Controversy | url=https://www.xconomy.com/san-francisco/2015/07/17/sharing-economy-companies-sharing-the-heat-in-contractor-controversy/ | first=Bernadette | last=Tansey | work=[[Xconomy]] | date=July 17, 2015}}</ref>
=====Underpayment of drivers===== In January 2017, Uber agreed to pay $20 million to the US government to resolve accusations by the [[Federal Trade Commission]] of having misled drivers about potential earnings.<ref>{{cite news | title=Uber to pay $20 million to settle U.S. claims it misled drivers | url=https://www.reuters.com/article/us-uber-ftc/uber-to-pay-20-million-to-settle-u-s-claims-it-misled-drivers-idUSKBN15334C | work=[[Reuters]] | first=Diane | last=Bartz | date=January 19, 2017}}</ref><ref>{{cite news | title=Uber to pay $20 million to FTC to settle claims that it exaggerated how much drivers would make | url=http://www.businessinsider.com/uber-to-pay-20-million-to-ftc-over-driver-earning-claims-2017-1 | first=Biz | last=Carson | work=[[Business Insider]] | date=January 20, 2017}}</ref><ref>{{cite news | title=Uber to Pay $20 Million to Settle FTC Suit Over Driver Pay | url=https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2017-01-19/uber-to-pay-20-million-to-settle-ftc-suit-over-driver-pay | first=Ellen | last=Huet | work=[[Bloomberg L.P.]] | date=January 19, 2017}}{{subscription required}}</ref>
=====Accusation of trade-secret theft by Waymo===== According to a February 2017 lawsuit filed by [[Waymo]], owned by an affiliate of [[Google]], ex-Google employee [[Anthony Levandowski]] allegedly "downloaded 9.7 GB of Waymo's highly confidential files and trade secrets, including blueprints, design files and testing documentation" before resigning to found [[Otto (company)|Otto]], which was purchased by Uber.<ref>{{cite news | url=https://www.nytimes.com/2017/02/24/technology/anthony-levandowski-waymo-uber-google-lawsuit.html | title=A Lawsuit Against Uber Highlights the Rush to Conquer Driverless Cars | first1=Mike | last1=Isaac | first2=Daisuke | last2=Wakabayashi | work=[[The New York Times]] | date=February 24, 2017}}{{subscription required}}</ref><ref>{{cite news | url=https://medium.com/waymo/a-note-on-our-lawsuit-against-otto-and-uber-86f4f98902a1 | title=A note on our lawsuit against Otto and Uber | work=[[Medium (website)|Medium]] | date=February 23, 2017}}</ref> A ruling in May 2017 required Uber to return documents to Waymo.<ref>{{cite news | url=https://www.reuters.com/article/us-uber-alphabet-ruling/uber-must-return-stolen-waymo-files-can-continue-self-driving-work-u-s-judge-idUSKCN18B1W6 | title=Uber must return stolen Waymo files, can continue self-driving work: U.S. judge | first1=Dan | last1=Levine | first2=Heather | last2=Somerville | work=[[Reuters]] | date= May 15, 2017}}</ref> The trial began February 5, 2018.<ref>{{cite news | last1=Farivar | first1=Cyrus | title=Waymo: "We're bringing this case because Uber is cheating" | url=https://arstechnica.com/tech-policy/2018/02/waymo-were-bringing-this-case-because-uber-is-cheating/ | work=[[Ars Technica]] | date=5 February 2018}}</ref> A settlement was announced February 8, 2018 with Uber giving Waymo $244 million in Uber equity and an agreement to ensure Uber does not infringe Waymo's intellectual property.<ref>{{cite news | last1=Farivar | first1=Cyrus | title=Silicon Valley's most-watched trial ends as Waymo and Uber settle | url=https://arstechnica.com/tech-policy/2018/02/waymo-and-uber-end-trial-with-sudden-244-million-settlement/ | work=[[Ars Technica]] | date=9 February 2018}}</ref>
=====Alleged short-changing of drivers===== In 2017 a lawsuit was filed alleging that Uber uses "sophisticated software" to defraud both drivers and passengers. According to the suit, under the upfront pricing model, when a passenger is quoted a price the app shows a longer more expensive route, meanwhile would-be drivers are shown a shorter cheaper route. The passenger is charged for the more expensive route, while the driver is paid the cheaper, with Uber pocketing the difference.<ref>{{cite news | url=https://www.independent.co.uk/news/business/news/uber-accused-of-extensive-methodical-scheme-to-short-change-drivers-us-lawsuit-upfront-pricing-a7673096.html | title=Uber accused of 'extensive, methodical scheme' to short-change drivers | last=Chapman | first=Ben | work=[[The Independent]] | date=7 April 2017}}</ref>
=====Denial of service to passenger with service animal===== In March 2018, a lawsuit was filed against Uber in the United States accusing the company's drivers of not serving a woman with [[cerebral palsy]] due to her [[service dog]] in violation of the [[Americans with Disabilities Act]] and the Texas Human Resources Code.<ref>{{cite news | last1=O'Kane | first1=Sean | title=Uber drivers denied service to woman with cerebral palsy, new lawsuit claims | url=https://www.theverge.com/2018/3/20/17144502/uber-lawsuit-service-dog-discrimination-disability | work=[[The Verge]] | publisher=[[Vox Media]] | date=March 20, 2018}}</ref><ref>{{cite news | last=Fingas | first=Jon | title=Uber faces lawsuit for denying rides to woman with service animal | url=https://www.engadget.com/2018/03/20/uber-lawsuit-over-service-animal-accessibility/ | work=[[Engadget]] | date=March 21, 2018}}</ref>
====Alaska==== In September 2015, Uber paid the State of Alaska $77,925 and paused operations in [[Anchorage]]. The state argued that Uber was misclassifying drivers as contractors instead of employees, which was illegal.<ref>{{cite news | title=Uber will pay fine to state workers' compensation division | url=https://www.adn.com/business/article/uber-agrees-pay-fine-state-workers-compensation-division/2015/09/04/ | first=Sean | last=Doogan | work=[[Anchorage Daily News]] | date=September 3, 2015}}</ref>
====California==== In May 2011, Uber received a [[cease-and-desist]] letter from the [[San Francisco Municipal Transportation Agency]], claiming it was operating an unlicensed taxi service, and another legal demand from the [[California Public Utilities Commission]] (CPUC) that it was operating an unlicensed limousine dispatch. Both claimed criminal violations and demanded that the company cease operations. In response, the company, among other things, changed its name from UberCab to Uber.<ref>{{cite web | last=Siegler | first=MG | url=https://techcrunch.com/2011/05/25/uber-airbnb-jail-time/ | title=Uber CEO: I Think I've Got 20,000 Years Of Jail Time In Front Of Me | work=[[TechCrunch]] | date=May 25, 2011}}</ref> In the fall of 2012, the CPUC issued a cease-and-desist letter to Uber, [[Lyft]], and [[SideCar (company)|SideCar]], and fined each $20,000.<ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.sfgate.com/business/article/Uber-Lyft-SideCar-hit-with-20K-fines-4037863.php | title=PUC fines 3 app-hailing taxi startups | first=Benny | last=Evangelista | work=[[San Francisco Chronicle]] | date=November 14, 2012}}</ref> However, an interim agreement was reached in 2013 reversing those actions.<ref>{{cite news | title=A Day After Cutting A Deal With Lyft, California Regulator Reaches An Agreement With Uber As Well | url=https://techcrunch.com/2013/01/31/a-day-after-cutting-a-deal-with-lyft-california-regulator-reaches-an-agreement-with-uber-as-well/ | last=Lawler | first=Ryan | work=[[TechCrunch]] | date=January 31, 2013}}</ref>
In June 2013, Lyft, Uber and Sidecar were served with cease and desist letters by the [[Los Angeles Department of Transportation]].<ref>{{cite news | url=https://www.cnet.com/news/uber-lyft-sidecar-get-cease-and-desist-letters-from-la/ | title=Uber, Lyft, Sidecar get cease-and-desist letters from LA | first=Dara | last=Kerr | work=[[CNET]] | date=June 25, 2013}}</ref>
In September 2013, the CPUC unanimously voted to make the agreement permanent, creating a new category of service called [[transportation network company]] to cover Lyft, UberX, SideCar, and [[Summon (company)|Summon]], thereby making California the first jurisdiction to recognize such services.<ref>{{cite news | last=Yeung | first=Ken | title=California Becomes First State To Regulate Ridesharing Services benefiting Uber, Lyft, Sidecar, and InstantCab | url=https://thenextweb.com/insider/2013/09/19/california-becomes-first-state-to-regulate-ride-sharing-services/ | work=TheNextWeb | date=September 19, 2013}}</ref><ref>{{cite news | url=https://www.forbes.com/sites/tomiogeron/2013/09/19/california-becomes-first-state-to-regulate-ridesharing-services-lyft-sidecar-uberx/ | title=California Becomes First State To Regulate Ridesharing Services Lyft, Sidecar, UberX | first=Tomio | last=Geron | work=[[Forbes]] | date=September 19, 2013}}</ref>
On September 17, 2014, California's Governor approved the "Assembly Bill No. 2293" bill that became effective on July 1, 2015. The bill amended "the Passenger Charter-party Carriers' Act to enact specified requirements for liability insurance coverage for transportation network companies, as defined, and their participating drivers." The driver under the law is defined as "any person who uses a vehicle in connection with a transportation network company's online-enabled application or platform to connect with passengers." The stated minimum insurance requirement ranges from US$50,000 to $100,000 for death and injuries per individual or incident, and stipulates US$30,000 for property damage. As a breach of the bill is classified as a criminal act, a corresponding "state-mandated local program" will be implemented.<ref>{{cite web | title=AB-2293 Transportation network companies: insurance coverage.(2013–2014) | url=http://leginfo.legislature.ca.gov/faces/billCompareClient.xhtml | publisher=California Legislative Information | date=17 September 2014}}</ref>
In April 2016, a case that was originally filed on December 9, 2014, by the [[district attorney]]s of both [[Los Angeles, California]], and San Francisco was resolved. Prosecutors claimed that Uber made misleading statements about the background checks it performs on drivers and falsely charged a "safe ride fee." The case was resolved when Uber agreed to no longer claim to be the "safest ride on the road", change the name of the "safe ride fee" to "booking fee", and pay $10 million.<ref>{{cite news | title=Uber's 'safe ride fee' becomes 'booking fee' after $25m settlement over rider safety | url=https://www.theguardian.com/technology/2016/apr/07/uber-driver-background-check-lawsuit-passenger-safety-california | last=Hern | first=Alex | work=[[The Guardian]] | date=7 April 2016}}</ref> San Francisco's city attorneys had previously settled out of court with Lyft over similar allegations.<ref>{{cite news | url=http://www.mercurynews.com/business/ci_27102694/biz-break-san-francisco-and-l-sue-uber | title=Biz Break: San Francisco and L.A. sue Uber, claim misleading and illegal actions | work=[[San Jose Mercury News]] | date=9 December 2014}}</ref>
On December 14, 2016, the California Department of Motor Vehicles demanded that Uber cease its [[autonomous car]] program in San Francisco or obtain a licence, threatening legal action.<ref>{{cite news | url=http://www.latimes.com/business/technology/la-fi-tn-uber-self-driving-sf-20161215-story.html | title=Uber's self-driving cars put tech's 'move fast, break things' credo to the test | first1=Tracey | last1=Lien | first2=Russ | last2=Mitchell | first3=Melissa | last3=Etehad | work=[[Los Angeles Times]] | date=December 15, 2016}}</ref><ref>{{cite news | url=https://www.theguardian.com/technology/2016/dec/21/witness-says-self-driving-uber-ran-red-light-on-its-own-disputing-ubers-claims | title=Witness says self-driving Uber ran red light on its own, disputing Uber's claims | first=Sam | last=Levin | work=[[The Guardian]] | date= December 21, 2016}}</ref> Following the invitation of tech enthusiast and Arizona Governor [[Doug Ducey]], Uber decided to move its fleet to Phoenix, Arizona.<ref>{{cite news | url=https://www.theguardian.com/technology/2016/dec/22/uber-self-driving-car-san-francisco-arizona | title=Uber packs up failed self-driving car trial in California and moves to Arizona | first=Julia Carrie | last=Wong | work=[[The Guardian]] | date=December 22, 2016}}</ref>
=====California employment law===== In a [[class action lawsuit]] filed in the [[United States District Court for the Northern District of California]] on August 16, 2013, Uber drivers plead that they were employees who had been misclassified as independent contractors in violation of the [[California Labor Code]] and demanded that they be given payment of business expenses such as gas and maintenance of their vehicles. In March 2015, District Judge [[Edward M. Chen]] ruled that the case will be resolved by a jury, dismissing a motion for [[summary judgement]].<ref>{{cite web | title=O'Connor v. Uber Technologies Inc. | url=https://h2o.law.harvard.edu/cases/5646 | publisher=[[Harvard University]] | date=March 11, 2015}}</ref> On September 1, 2015, Chen certified the class but generally limited it to drivers in California hired before June 2014, when an opt-out arbitration clause was included in the contract, who had directly contracted with Uber.<ref name=NYT9115>{{cite news |title=Uber Rebuffed by Judge in Ruling on Drivers' Suit | url=https://www.nytimes.com/2015/09/02/technology/uber-rebuffed-by-judge-in-ruling-on-drivers-suit.html | first=Mike | last=Isaac | work=[[The New York Times]] | date=September 1, 2015}}</ref><ref name=C13-3826>{{cite web | title=O'Connor v. Uber Technologies, Inc. et al., C13-3826 EMC | url=http://www.cand.uscourts.gov/EMC/OConnorvUberTechnologies | publisher=[[United States District Court for the Northern District of California]]}}</ref>
====Colorado==== In June 2014, Colorado became the first state to pass rules for TNCs through the legislative process, when S 125 was signed into law.<ref>{{cite news | url=http://www.denverpost.com/business/ci_25907057/colorado-first-authorize-lyft-and-ubers-ridesharing-services | title=Colorado first to authorize Lyft and Uber's ridesharing services | work=[[The Denver Post]] | date=June 5, 2014}}</ref>
====Georgia==== In September 2014, a class-action lawsuit was filed by taxicab drivers claiming that Uber drivers were not properly licensed.<ref>{{cite news | url=https://www.ajc.com/business/atlanta-taxicab-drivers-sue-uber-ride-sharing-service/s8fQWG0S0x2167xGDCXSLJ/ | title=Atlanta taxicab drivers sue Uber ride-sharing service | first=Christopher | last=Seward | work=[[Atlanta Journal Constitution]] | date=September 10, 2014}}</ref> The lawsuit was dismissed by the Georgia Supreme Court.<ref>{{cite news | url=https://www.ajc.com/news/local/court-rejects-atlanta-taxi-lawsuit-over-competition-from-uber-lyft/HlQcvoLEoVR0O7RB3Yik9M/ | title=Court rejects Atlanta taxi lawsuit over competition from Uber, Lyft | first= David | last=Wickert | work=[[Atlanta Journal Constitution]] | date=May 15, 2017}}</ref>
====Illinois==== On October 5, 2012, Uber was sued by the taxi and livery companies in Chicago. Uber was accused of violating Chicago city laws and [[Illinois]] state laws designed to protect public safety, consumer protection, and fair practices.<ref>{{cite news | url=https://techcrunch.com/2012/10/05/uber-sued-by-taxi-and-livery-companies-in-chicago-for-consumer-fraud-and-more/ | title=Uber Sued By Taxi And Livery Companies In Chicago For Consumer Fraud And More | first=Leena | last=Rao | work=[[TechCrunch]] | date=October 5, 2012}}</ref> Regulations affecting TNCs were approved in December 2014.<ref>{{cite news | last=Dalike | first=Jim | title=Regulations on Uber and Lyft Get Ironed Out As Illinois Lawmakers Approve Ridesharing Bill | url=http://chicagoinno.streetwise.co/2014/12/04/uber-lyft-see-ridesharing-regulations-with-illinois-bill/ | publisher=ChicagoInno | date=December 4, 2014}}</ref>
====Massachusetts==== On August 1, 2012, the [[Massachusetts]] Division of Standards issued a cease-and-desist letter to Uber on the grounds that the GPS-based smartphone app was not a certified measurement device, but on August 15, the agency reversed its ruling after prodding by Governor [[Deval Patrick]], saying that technique was satisfactory because it was under study by the [[National Institute of Standards and Technology]].<ref>{{cite news | url=https://www.boston.com/uncategorized/noprimarytagmatch/2012/08/15/state-reverses-ban-on-uber-car-service-ordering-app | title=State reverses ban on Uber car service ordering app | first=Michael B. | last=Farrell | work=[[The Boston Globe]] | date=August 15, 2012}}</ref>
Uber worked out an arrangement with the city of Boston to share quarterly data on the duration, locations, and times of day in which riders used the app to travel in or out of the city. This information was first delivered to the city in February 2015, and the report kept all individual user data private.<ref>{{cite news | title=In first, Uber to share ride data with Boston | first=Nicole | last=Dungca | url=https://www.bostonglobe.com/business/2015/01/13/uber-share-ridership-data-with-boston/4Klo40KZREtQ7jkoaZjoNN/story.html | work=[[The Boston Globe]] | date=January 13, 2015}}</ref>
The legislature passed a law formally legalizing and regulating TNCs in July 2016.<ref name=legiscan>{{cite web | url=https://legiscan.com/MA/text/H4570/2015 | title=Massachusetts H4570 – 2015–2016 – 189th General Court}}</ref> The law requires background checks, vehicle decals and inspections, insurance, state certification of drivers; prohibits increased fares during a declared emergency or for passengers with disabilities; requires drivers to be 21 or older; and sets up a complaint process and commission to review the economics of the whole ride-for-hire industry. Unlike taxis, TNC vehicles are prohibited from "cruising" for passengers on streets. The law also establishes a $0.20 per-ride charge, which is distributed to cities and towns for transportation and ride-for-hire economic development purposes.
====Michigan==== In December 2016, Michigan instituted regulations on TNCs.<ref>{{cite news | url=http://www.detroitnews.com/story/news/local/michigan/2016/12/01/uber-regulations/94744106/ | title=Michigan Senate green lights Uber, Lyft regulations | first=Jonathan | last=Oosting | work=[[Detroit News]] | date=December 1, 2016}}</ref>
====Minnesota==== In July 2014, the Minneapolis City Council voted almost unanimously to legalize TNCs.<ref>{{cite news | url=http://www.startribune.com/local/blogs/267685111.html | title=Minneapolis joins other cities regulating Lyft, UberX | first=Eric | last=Roper | work=[[Star Tribune]] | date=July 18, 2014}}</ref>
====Nevada==== On November 25, 2014, [[Washoe County, Nevada]] [[State court (United States)|District Court]] Judge Scott Freeman, issued a [[preliminary injunction]] preventing Uber from operating statewide. The temporary injunction was based on the company's failure to file a [[certificate of public convenience and necessity]], which is required for every transportation service in Nevada. The [[Government of Nevada]] also claimed that Uber's screening process was not rigorous enough to protect consumers, and failed to conform with the aforementioned regulations. Uber contested the ruling, arguing that it is an app-based technology company rather than a transportation company, but the company's management made the decision to temporarily shut down its Nevada operations.<ref>{{cite news | url=https://www.reuters.com/article/us-usa-nevada-ridesharing-idUSKCN0JB18J20141127 | title=Ridesharing firm Uber suspends operations in Nevada | first=Eric M. | last=Johnson | work=[[Reuters]] | date=November 27, 2014}}</ref> Nevada legalized TNCs in May 2015.<ref>{{cite news | url=http://www.latimes.com/business/la-fi-uber-nevada-20150528-story.html | title=Uber gets big win in Nevada as Legislature OKs bill authorizing service | first=Tracy | last=Lieman | work=[[Los Angeles Times]] | date=May 27, 2015}}{{subscription required}}</ref>
====New Hampshire==== Legislation passed in 2016 in New Hampshire requires each TNC (not each driver) to pay an annual fee of $500. It also includes requirements that each TNC get a permit from the state, obtain a driver history report on each driver that meets the provisions of the law, and require their drivers to have liability insurance.<ref>{{cite news | url=http://www.nhbr.com/May-13-2016/NH-Senate-OKs-Uber-regulations/ | title=NH Senate OKs Uber regulations | first=Bob |last=Sanders | work=[[New Hampshire Business Review]] | date=May 13, 2016}}</ref>
====New York==== UberX was suspended in [[New York City]] in October 2012 after pressure from the [[New York City Taxi and Limousine Commission]]. Uber's premium sedan service was not affected.<ref>{{cite news | url=https://www.engadget.com/2012/10/16/uber-shuts-down-new-york-city-taxi-beta | title=Uber shuts down New York City taxi beta, may see light at the end of the (Lincoln) tunnel in February (update: TLC responds) | work=[[Engadget]]}}</ref>
In January 2017, the New York City Taxi Workers Alliance called for a halt in pickups from [[JFK Airport]] in New York City in response to [[Donald Trump]]'s [[Executive Order 13769]], which banned entry to the United States from citizens of 7 predominately Muslim countries.<ref name="jfk" /> Uber users accused the company of attempting to profit from the strike and were angered that Uber did not halt pickups from JFK Airport in solidarity.<ref name="fascism" /> Some users deleted the Uber app from their phones.<ref name="fascism">{{cite news|url=https://www.cnbc.com/2017/01/29/uber-customers-lash-out-at-ride-sharing-service-amid-anti-travel-ban-protests.html|title='Uber supports fascism!' Furious users lash out at ride sharing service amid travel ban protest|last=David|first=Javier E.|date=January 29, 2017|work=[[CNBC]]}}</ref><ref name="jfk">{{cite news|url=https://www.businessinsider.com/delete-uber-hashtag-jfk-airport-taxi-strikes-2017-1|title=Furious customers are deleting the Uber app after drivers went to JFK airport during a protest and strike|date=January 29, 2017|work=[[Business Insider]]}}</ref> Kalanick responded by signing an open letter to President [[Donald Trump]] that requested he rescind his executive order.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.forbes.com/sites/alexkonrad/2017/01/30/ny-tech-leaders-and-uber-ceo-oppose-immigration-ban/|title=Uber CEO Travis Kalanick Joins NY Tech Leaders In Letter Opposing Immigration Ban|last=Konrad|first=Alex|date=January 30, 2017|work=[[Forbes]]}}</ref>
In May 2017, after a class action lawsuit was filed by the New York Taxi Workers Alliance (NYTWA) in federal court in New York, Uber admitted to underpaying New York City drivers tens of millions of dollars over 2.5 years by calculating driver commissions on a net amount. Uber agreed to pay the amounts owed plus interest.<ref>{{cite news | url=https://www.theguardian.com/technology/2017/may/23/uber-underpaid-drivers-new-york-city | title=Uber admits underpaying New York City drivers by millions of dollars | first=Julia Carrie | last=Wong | work=[[The Guardian]] | date=May 23, 2017}}</ref>
In February 2017, the [[New York State Senate]] approved legislation allowing TNCs to expand operations to [[Upstate New York]] and Uber began service there in June 2017.<ref>{{cite news | url=http://www.newyorkupstate.com/news/2017/06/uber_lyft_set_to_start_at_1201_am_thursday_at_upstate_ny.html | title=Uber, Lyft set to start at 12:01 a.m. Thursday in Upstate NY | first=Patrick | last=Lohmann | work=[[Advance Publications]] | date=June 26, 2017}}</ref>
====North Carolina==== In September 2015, Governor [[Pat McCrory]] signed a law regulating TNCs. It also forbids the establishment by county and municipal governments of additional regulations upon TNCs and drivers.<ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.ncleg.net/Sessions/2015/Bills/Senate/PDF/S541v5.pdf | title=Senate Bill 541: An Act to Regulate Transportation Network Companies | publisher=[[North Carolina General Assembly]] | date=September 4, 2015}}</ref>
====Oregon==== [[File:Uber Protest Portland (15655460313).jpg|thumbnail|A protest against Uber in Portland, Oregon in January 2015]] On December 8, 2014, [[Portland, Oregon]] sued Uber, claiming that Uber violates the city's Private for Hire Transportation Regulations and Administrative Rules. The court was asked to stop Uber from operating in Portland.<ref>{{cite press release | url=http://www.portlandoregon.gov/transportation/article/511920 | title= City of Portland sues Uber for operating illegal, unregulated transportation service | date=December 8, 2014}}</ref> Uber suspended its operations in the city for 3 months, pending planned changes to local regulations.<ref>{{cite news | url=https://www.theverge.com/2014/12/18/7418195/uber-halting-its-operations-in-portland-for-3-months-after-being-sued | title=Uber halting its operations in Portland for 3 months while a deal is worked out | first=Josh | last=Lowensohn | work=[[The Verge]] | publisher=[[Vox Media]] | date=December 18, 2014}}</ref>
=====Portland investigation into Greyball===== On March 6, 2017, the City of [[Portland, Oregon]] announced an investigation into whether Uber had used its Greyball software tool to obstruct the enforcement of city regulations.<ref>{{cite news | url=https://www.oregonlive.com/commuting/index.ssf/2017/03/ubers_greyball_scheme_to_thwar.html | title=Portland to investigate Uber's 'Greyball' scheme to thwart regulators | last=Njus | first=Elliot | work=[[The Oregonian]] | date=March 6, 2017}}</ref> The investigation by the Portland Bureau of Transportation (PBOT) found that:
{{quote |text=When Uber illegally entered the Portland market in December 2014, the company tagged 17 individual rider accounts, 16 of which have been identified as government officials using its Greyball software tool. Uber used Greyball software to intentionally evade PBOT’s officers from December 5 to December 19, 2014 and deny 29 separate ride requests by PBOT enforcement officers.<ref>{{cite web | publisher=[[Portland Bureau of Transportation]] | url=https://www.portlandoregon.gov/saltzman/article/637492 | title=Transportation Network Companies: Regulation Evasion Audit | date=April 28, 2017}}</ref>}}
Following the release of the audit, Portland's commissioner of police suggested that the city subpoena Uber in order to force the company to turn over information on how Uber used software to evade regulatory officials.<ref>{{cite news | last=Njus | first=Elliot | title=Portland may subpoena Uber over regulator-dodging 'Greyball' software | url=http://www.oregonlive.com/commuting/index.ssf/2017/04/portland_may_subpoena_uber_ove.html | work=[[The Oregonian]] | date=April 27, 2017}}</ref>
====Pennsylvania==== On July 1, 2014, after implementing fines on Uber and Lyft, the [[Pennsylvania Public Utility Commission]] imposed a cease-and-desist order on the companies.<ref>{{cite news | url=https://www.pghcitypaper.com/pittsburgh/uber-just-celebrated-its-second-anniversary-in-pittsburgh-but-drivers-say-working-for-the-company-is-no-party/Content?oid=1897263 | title=Uber, other ride-sharing firms given green light to pick up passengers at Pittsburgh airport | first=Kim | last=Lyons | work=[[Pittsburgh City Paper]] | date=February 24, 2016}}</ref>
=====Pittsburgh===== In June 2015, Uber drivers became eligible to pick up riders at [[Pittsburgh International Airport]].<ref>{{cite news | url=http://www.post-gazette.com/news/transportation/2015/06/02/Uber-allowed-to-pick-up-passengers-at-Pittsburgh-International-Airport/stories/201506020186 | title=Uber, other ride-sharing firms given green light to pick up passengers at Pittsburgh airport | first=Luke | last=Nozicka | work=[[Pittsburgh Post-Gazette]] | date=June 2, 2015}}</ref>
=====Philadelphia===== In December 2014, [[Checker Cab]] Philadelphia and 44 other taxi companies in [[Philadelphia, Pennsylvania]] filed a lawsuit alleging that Uber was operating illegally in the city.<ref>{{cite web | title=Complaint, Checker Cab Philadelphia, Inc. et al v. Uber Technologies, Inc. et al | url=https://www.pacermonitor.com/view/DUNI3NQ/CHECKER_CAB_PHILADELPHIA_INC_et_v_UBER_TECHNOLOGIES_INC_et_al__paedce-14-07265__0001.0.pdf | publisher=PacerMonitor}}</ref><ref>{{cite news | url=http://www.philly.com/philly/business/20141225_Uber_slapped_with_suit_by_45_city_taxi_companies.html | title=Uber slapped with suit by 45 Phila. taxi companies | work=[[The Philadelphia Inquirer]] | first=Erin | last=Arvedlund | authorlink=Erin Arvedlund | date=December 25, 2014}}</ref> On March 3, 2015, U.S. District Judge Nitza I. Quinones Alejandro denied a motion for a preliminary injunction against Uber.<ref>{{cite news | title=Judge Nixes Attempt To Keep Uber Out of Philly | url=https://www.law360.com/articles/627686/judge-nixes-attempt-to-keep-uber-out-of-philly| first=Alex | last=Wolf | work=[[Law360]] | date=March 4, 2015}}</ref>
In January 2016, a $1.5M lawsuit was filed against Uber in Philadelphia by Philadelphia taxicab medallion owners, claiming that Uber engaged in [[tortious interference]] and engaged in false advertising under the Lanham Act. The case was dismissed in August 2016.<ref>{{cite web | title=Coachtrans v. Uber Technologies | url=https://www.gpo.gov/fdsys/pkg/USCOURTS-paed-2_16-cv-00088/pdf/USCOURTS-paed-2_16-cv-00088-0.pdf | publisher=[[United States District Court for the Eastern District of Pennsylvania]] | date=August 19, 2016}}</ref>
Philadelphia legalized TNCs in November 2016.<ref>{{cite news | url=http://www.philly.com/philly/business/transportation/Uber-and-Lyft-made-44-million-since-becoming-legal-in-Philadelphia.html | title=Uber and Lyft made $44 million since becoming legal in Philadelphia | first=Jason | last=Laughlin | work=[[Philadelphia Media Network]] | date=February 16, 2017}}</ref>
====Texas==== =====Austin===== In March 2015, UberPOOL began operations in [[Austin, Texas]] in advance of the annual [[South by Southwest]] festival.<ref name=Lawler15>{{cite news | title=Uber And Lyft Urge Users To Share Rides With Other Passengers During SXSW | first=Ryan | last=Lawler | url=https://techcrunch.com/2015/03/09/uber-pool-lyft-line-sxsw/ | work=[[TechCrunch]] | date=March 9, 2015}}</ref>
On May 7, 2016, Uber and Lyft announced they would no longer provide service in Austin after city voters rejected a referendum backed by the TNCs that would have repealed a city ordinance requiring their drivers to submit to fingerprint-based background checks.<ref>{{cite news | title=Uber, Lyft Shut Down in Austin Over Fingerprint Vote | url=https://www.wsj.com/articles/texas-capital-city-votes-to-keep-fingerprinting-for-uber-lyft-drivers-1462796972 | first1=Douglas | last1=MacMillan | first2=Rachel Emma | last2=Silverman| work=[[The Wall Street Journal]] | date=May 9, 2016}}{{subscription required}}</ref>
=====Houston===== In late 2016, Uber threatened to leave [[Houston]] ahead of [[Super Bowl LI]], insisting various city regulations, including fingerprint background checks of drivers, were too burdensome. Houston officials and Uber reached a compromise in December 2016, whereby Houston would continue to require a fingerprint check for drivers but eliminate requirements for driver drug testing and physicals through at least February 5, 2017.<ref>{{cite web | url=http://mashable.com/2017/02/03/uber-super-bowl-houston/#KU1P7afA5PqJ | title=Uber barely hangs on in Houston ahead of Super Bowl, while Airbnb claims 'biggest nights ever' | last=Hinchliffe | first=Emma | work=[[Mashable]] | date=February 3, 2017}}</ref>
====Tennessee==== Regulations affecting TNCs were implemented in December 2014.<ref>{{cite news | last=Garrison | first=Joey | title=Uber, Lyft regulations approved in Nashville | url=http://www.tennessean.com/story/news/politics/2014/12/16/uber-lyft-regulations-approved-nashville/20515557/ | work=[[The Tennessean]] | date=16 December 2014}}</ref>
====Virginia==== On June 5, 2014, the [[Virginia Department of Motor Vehicles]] issued a cease-and-desist letter to both Uber and Lyft, demanding they halt operations within [[Virginia]].<ref>{{cite news | url=http://hamptonroads.com/node/718716 | title=Virginia DMV orders Lyft, Uber to stop operating | first=Dave | last=Forster | work=[[The Virginian-Pilot]] | date=June 5, 2014}}</ref> In February 2015, TNCs were legalized in Virginia.<ref>{{cite news | url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/news/dr-gridlock/wp/2015/02/18/uber-and-lyft-are-now-legal-in-virginia/ | title=Uber and Lyft are now legal in Virginia | first=Luz | last=Lazo | work=[[The Washington Post]] | date=February 18, 2015}}</ref>
====Washington==== In March 2014, to appease taxi drivers, the Seattle City Council passed an ordinance in March 2014 that capped the number of drivers from any TNC on the road at any given time to 150.<ref>{{cite news | url=https://techcrunch.com/2014/03/17/seattle-hates-ride-sharing/ | title=Seattle Deals A Blow To Uber And Lyft By Limiting The Number Of Ride-Sharing Drivers On The Road | first=Ryan | last=Lawler | work=[[TechCrunch]] | date=March 17, 2014}}</ref> However, on April 17, 2014, after a coalition obtained 36,000 signatures to put the question to voters in a referendum, Mayor [[Ed Murray (Washington politician)|Ed Murray]] announced a 45-day negotiation process to find an alternative approach.<ref>{{cite news | url=http://www.geekwire.com/2014/ride-sharing-petition-seattle/ | title=Seattle ride-sharing regulations suspended; Mayor wants to negotiate with stakeholders | first=Taylor | last=Soper | work=[[GeekWire]] | date=April 17, 2014}}</ref> Uber donated over $613,000 to "Seattle Citizens to Repeal Ordinance 124441", a political group seeking to overturn the ordinance limiting the number of TNC vehicles in Seattle.<ref>{{cite web | title=Contributions to Seattle Citizens to Repeal Ordinance 124441 2014 Election Cycle | url=http://web6.seattle.gov/ethics/elections/poplist.aspx?cid=374&listtype=contributors | publisher=Seattle Ethics and Elections Commission}}</ref> In June 2014, the mayor reached a deal to legalize TNCs with no driver limits.<ref>{{cite news | url=https://www.geekwire.com/2014/seattle-legalizes-uber-lyft-caps/ | title=Seattle mayor reaches deal to legalize Uber, Lyft and Sidecar, without driver limits | first=Taylor | last=Soper | work=[[GeekWire]] | date=June 16, 2014}}</ref> The compromise was passed by the city council in July 2014.<ref>{{cite news | url=https://www.seattlemet.com/articles/2014/7/14/city-council-finally-legalizes-ridesharing-july-2014 | title=City Council Legalizes Ridesharing | first=Erica C. | last=Barnett | work=[[Seattle Metropolitan]] | date=July 14, 2014}}</ref>
====Washington, D.C.==== In January 2012, an Uber driver's car was impounded as part of a sting by the Washington, D.C. taxicab commission. The commissioner said the company was operating an unlicensed taxicab service in the city.<ref>{{cite news | last=Greene | first=David | url=https://www.npr.org/2012/01/31/146123433/upstart-car-service-butts-heads-with-d-c-s-taxis | title=Upstart Car Service Butts Heads With D.C.'s Taxis | work=[[NPR]] | date=January 31, 2012}}</ref> Following a social media campaign by Uber riders, the D.C. city council voted in July 2012 to formally legalize TNCs, which led to protests by taxicab drivers.<ref>{{cite news | url=https://bits.blogs.nytimes.com/2012/07/10/uber-vs-washington-dc/ | work=[[The New York Times]] | first=Brian X. | last=Chen | title=Uber, Maker of Summon-a-Car App, Wins in Washington | date=July 10, 2012}}{{subscription required}}</ref> The Washington, D.C. City Council passed legislation in September 2013 to allow TNCs to operate.<ref>{{cite news | url=https://www.gwhatchet.com/2013/09/17/cheh-evans-pass-legislation-to-protect-uber-from-city-regulations/ | title=Cheh, Evans pass legislation to protect Uber from city regulations | first=Colleen | last=Murphy | work=[[GW Hatchet]] | date=September 17, 2013}}</ref>
===Ukraine=== On March 30, 2017, taxi drivers protested against Uber and [[Yandex.Taxi]] in [[Lviv]].<ref>{{cite news | url=http://qha.com.ua/en/photo/lviv-taxi-drivers-protested-against-yandex-taxi-and-uber/28850/ | title=Lviv taxi drivers protested against Yandex.Taxi and UBER | publisher=QHA | date=31 March 2017}}</ref>

<!-- UN-related article; UN spelling/stylistic conventions--> {{Infobox Treaty | name = United Nations Millennium Declaration | long_name = | image = Emblem of the United Nations.svg | image_width = | caption = | type = | date_drafted = | date_signed = 8 September 2000 | location_signed = | date_sealed = | date_effective = | condition_effective = | date_expiration = | signatories = | parties = | depositor = | language = | languages = | website = | wikisource = United Nations Millennium Declaration }} On 8 September 2000, following a three-day [[Millennium Summit]] of world leaders at the headquarters of the [[United Nations]], the [[United Nations General Assembly|General Assembly]] adopted the '''Millennium Declaration (Resolution 55/2)'''.{{sfn |UN|2000}} A follow-up outcome of the resolution was passed by the General Assembly on 14 December 2000 to guide its implementation. Progress on implementation of the Declaration was reviewed at the [[2005 World Summit]] of leaders.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.un.org/en/events/pastevents/worldsummit_2005.shtml|title=United Nations Conferences, Meetings and Events|website=www.un.org|language=FR|access-date=2018-01-30}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.un.org/womenwatch/ods/A-RES-60-1-E.pdf|title=2005 World Summit Outcome|last=|first=|date=|website=|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=30 January 2018}}</ref> The Declaration includes 8 chapters and 32 paragraphs.
==Chapters== The Millennium Declaration has eight chapters and key objectives, adopted by 189 world leaders during the summit: The Declaration, after the [[Vienna Declaration and Programme of Action]], stresses the observance of [[international human rights law]] and [[international humanitarian law]] under the Principles of [[United Nations Charter]] as well as the treaties on [[sustainable development]]. The Declaration also urges observance of the [[Olympic truce]] individually and collectively. #Values and Principles :*Freedom :*Equality :*Solidarity :*Tolerance :*Respect for nature - "Shown in the management of all living species and natural resources, in accordance with the precepts of sustainable development." :*Shared responsibility #<li value="2">[[Peace]], Security and [[Disarmament]] #[[right to development|Development]] and [[poverty reduction|Poverty Eradication]] #[[Environmental protection|Protecting our Common Environment]] #[[Human Rights]], [[Democracy]] and Good [[Governance]] #Protecting the [[social vulnerability|Vulnerable]] #Meeting the Special Needs of [[Africa]] #Strengthening the United Nations

Hare Road, [[Ramna]], [[Dhaka]] |termlength = |formation = 17 April 1971 |first = [[Syed Nazrul Islam]] |abolished = 6 December 1990 |last = [[Shahabuddin Ahmed]] }} {{Politics of Bangladesh}} The '''Vice-President of Bangladesh''' was formerly the second highest constitutional office in [[Bangladesh]], when the country was governed under a [[presidential system]]. The Vice-President was the first person in the presidential line of succession, in the event of a President's resignation, removal or death. The post was held by several Bangladeshi statesmen during different periods of the country's history. The inaugural office holder was [[Syed Nazrul Islam]] during the [[Bangladesh Liberation War]]. The final office holder was [[Shahabuddin Ahmed]]. [[Abdus Sattar (president)|Abdus Sattar]] was the only vice-president to succeed to the presidency in 1981. The office was first created in the [[Provisional Government of Bangladesh]] in 1971. It was later revived in 1977, abolished in the [[1982 Bangladesh coup d'état|1982 coup d'état]]; and reinstated in 1986. It was abolished again during the [[Constitution of Bangladesh#Twelfth Amendment|Twelfth Amendment to the Constitution]]. ==Key== ;''Political parties'' *{{legend|{{Bangladesh Awami League/meta/color}}|[[Bangladesh Awami League]]|border=1px solid #AAAAAA}} *{{legend|{{Bangladesh Nationalist Party/meta/color}}|[[Bangladesh Nationalist Party]]|border=1px solid #AAAAAA}} *{{legend|{{Jatiya Party (Ershad)/meta/color}}|[[Jatiya Party (Ershad)|Jatiya Party]]|border=1px solid #AAAAAA}} ;''Other factions'' *{{legend|{{Independent (politician)/meta/color}}|[[Independent politician|Independent]]|border=1px solid #AAAAAA}} ==Vice-Presidents== {| class="wikitable" style="text-align:center" ! {{Abbr|No.|Number}} ! A '''War referendum''' is a proposed type of [[referendum]] in which citizens decide whether a nation should go to war. No such referendum has taken place.
The earliest idea of a war referendum came from [[Marquis de Condorcet]] in 1793 and [[Immanuel Kant]] in 1795.<ref name="ballot">{{Cite book |last=Bolt, Jr. |first=Ernest C. |authorlink= |coauthors= |year=1977 |title=Ballots Before Bullets, The War Referendum Approach to Peace in America 1914-1941 |publisher=University Press of Virginia |location=Charlottesville |isbn=0813906628 }}p. xii-xiii</ref>
